Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2010 08:19AM ElaineD wrote: I'm so glad that you decided to post over on this forum, and so will get the benefit of the experiences of those who really know and understand what you are dealing with. I'm so sorry that this has come to you so young in life. I'm nearly twice your age, and feel that I've been "robbed" of what could have been some of the best years of my life. I don't expect to live to see 60 (although will do everything to try!)-and certainly won't reach the proverbial three score years plus 10-I would be happy to drift off after this age! I can't begin to imagine the added stresses that this brings into your life-at a time when you should be having fun with your babies, you are having to fight for survival-it's just not right. Cancer is cruel at any age-but it infuriates me when it hits someone so young. At least those of us who are middle aged had a good spell of health before having to deal with this. But-as I've said before-there are many treatments available for you to try-and no reason not to feel that some of them may be succesful for you. Do ask if you have any questions-and we will do our utmost to help/advise and support-there is so much to take on board in the early days. it's a bit like information overload, so try to go as slowly as you can on this front-and anything you don't understand-shout out! There's a good chance one of us may have the answer/some suggestions.Hugs to you all,x

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 10:45AM ElaineD wrote: Yet another liver mets girl-there are quite a lot of us! Sadly the liver is notoriously hard to treat, and like the others, I've had a fair go on the various chemos. To date I've had taxotere, xeloda, carboplatin and navelbine. We got some response from tax and carbo, nothing from the other two-but sadly any reduction tends to be shortlived. At present I'm on taxol-just had cycle 2 yesterday, so hoping that helps. I'm surprised yor onc moved you on after only 1 cycle-that really isn't long enough to judge if something will hep or not. We always give it 3 cycles, scan, then make a decision. To date have had no bloating nor tenderness-an occasional twinge which lasts only a few seconds.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2009 11:17PM ElaineD wrote: I'm no longer on xeloda, as it didn't work for me. However, I can sympathise with your Mum's problems. My hands and feet were in a dreadful mess, and I could scarcely stand. Initially the dosage was reduced, which helped slightly. But when the scan showed that it wasn't working for me, I must admit to being relieved that I no longer had to take it. On the plus side....within weeks of stopping the drug, improvements in the symptoms was very noticeable,and such a relief. There are many chemos available-your Mum might be more comfortable with another drug, if her symptoms keep getting worse.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 01:37PM ElaineD wrote: If you are undecided+/or have doubts, don't do it! There are pros and cons to both having the test, and not. But-if you do have the test, and get a positive result, it's not something that you will then be able to forget about. So you have to be completely convinced before setting this into motion. Most genetic cancers, however tend to strike (on average-this is not written in stone!) about 10 years earlier than the previous onset. So it could be wise to make a decision one way or another quite soon. Good luck-it's a very hard decision to make-but keep in mind, even if your family did have the genetic misprint, it's by no means a certainty that you would have it. I'm BRCA2-and exactly 50% of the family who have been tested so far are also positive-but 50% are negative, of course!

But, in your heart, you know that you've had a good response-and measurable reduction is always a cause for relief, joy and happiness. But this is no dream, it's your reality. Hey, wait....it's your dream come true!

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 09:03AM ElaineD wrote: I've never been a pretty girl/girly girl type-you know what I mean! Having said that, I have to admit that I'm perfectly comfortable in my own skin, and genuinely believe that appearances don't matter. I think this in part has helped me cope with mastectomies (no reconstruction), and compression bandages. But I fully understand the sentiment, "who is this?" I  think the same at times when I see my reflection in a shop window, or a mirror. Weight for me is going in the opposite direction to the rest of you-I'm very slight (about 44 kilos at the mo!), and that in itself is scary. The grey hair doesn't bother me-but the pasty, colourless cheeks do. I look like what I am-a sick middle aged girl, who is struggling. Really not what I expected at this moment in time. However, those who love me don't care what I look like-and that is comforting up to a point. I guess I could make more effort, and that may make a difference-but as I've never been overly concerned with appearance before, why should I start now? Just wish I wasn't announcing it to the world-I don't resent the pitying glances in my direction, but they are upsetting. I haev a friend who is also stage 1V-and she looks stunning. The down side to this, is that everyone expects her to get better and be cured! We can't win!

Posts.Title: Carboplatin alone? LC815 ElaineD

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2009 03:49AM ElaineD wrote: So sorry to hear your news-but with your family history, I think that your worries are perfectly understandable. At your age, genetic testing is likely to be a good thing for you (if you were younger, then accurate readings are difficult, as the tissue is dense in younger woman.) But clearly this comes with a lot of emotional stress. How would you feel if you tested positive for the genetic forms of cancer? But, on the plus side it would give you the option to plan your future-at least in terms of having children. I don't know where you are from-if America, I can't advise on how the system works. But here (UK), anyone seeking genetic testing has a few sessions first with a geneticist, to discuss worries, fears, etc, before they go ahead and do the test. This can be very helpful. Our daughter, for example, was diagnosed as having the gene misprint when she was 22-and is glad she knows. Whereas our son, after several meetings decided not to be tested. Neither of them were pressurised in any way to change their minds, by either the professionals, or ourselves. As a very rough rule of thumb, genetic cancers tend to strike about 10 years earlier than the preceding family member-but that is a very rough guide! I'm so glad that you have such good support from your bf and sister-this will be invaluable in the weeks ahead. I hope your worries turn out t be unfounded. Please keep us posted, and good luck.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 11:59AM ElaineD wrote: Another one who understands Lynn. It hurts so much when our closest family live in denial-ok, perhaps it helps them cope, and so I guess we should be grateful for that at least. Even here, we often see sisters claiming they're aiming to be cured/hoping for a cure soon-so denial is probably a more common reaction than we think. I'm always torn between saying "wake up to reality", or "dream on..." Perhaps one in a milion (hundreds of thousands?), may have a cure, defy all odds and live for much longer than expected. But for the vast majority, we know which road we are walking, and the likely destination. I'd still like to have a period of stability though-just a brief respite from the endless treatmnet, and all it brings, both mentally and physically.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2009 11:51PM ElaineD wrote: I can see both points of view. Your onc's stand is quite logical, and of course is true-NED doesn't last indefinitely. But how wondreful it must be to have it occasionally/regularly (am still aiming to get there!) In the meantime, enjoy the fact that you are responding to treatment-whatever it is called. It does worry me when we see people hoping for "cure"/no recurrence, both situations which are pretty much unattainable. But if you can accept and enjoy the "good" periods, while remaining alert to further problems, then you're doing great-not just physically, but mentally too by accepting the constant challenges with which we have to live. Good luck that this lasts a very long time for you!

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2010 10:09AM ElaineD wrote: I think nobody gets it because we all try to analyse it too much. What has happened, why it has happened, its so unfair, so let's rant and rage about it all, etc, etc. This in some ways actually detracts from the whole battle (and I make no apologies for using fighting terminology-I am fighting for my life, so why pretend otherwise?) We all need to talk and share-and I assume that you are at the very early stage yet, so everything is new, frightening, and bewildering. But you're right-nobody gets it-our nearest and dearest family and friends-and it's a point we often make on this particular board too. Unless you have a stage 1V diagnosis, it's impossible to relate/understand our concerns/treatments and lifestyles. In some respects, being the sister/husband/daughter of a patient is even worse-as patients we have no choice other than to take any treatments which are available, for as long as we feel we can cope with them. On the other hand, our nearest and dearest can only watch as we suffer....That's not to say that we don't value and appreciate the support of our loved ones-but how I wish we could spare them this. If I had a worst enemy, I wouldn't wish this on them!

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 10:20AM ElaineD wrote: How can we really celebrate 1 year taken off our already foreshoretend lives? Before this disease, birthdays were to be celebrated-I feel metversaries are almost the opposite-a clear reminder of time passing for us-and we don't have the luxury of thinking/hoping to have many more. I try not to think of them at all-ironic really, as had I known at met diagnosis that I would survive 3 years (so far)-I would have been delighted. But of course, 3 years down the track, and it feels like nothing-I want much more. But have to accept that I won't get many more. I'm not being pessimistic, I don't think-just realistic enough to accept that our situations are dire. I don't discount miracles happening-but it would be foolish to expect to be the one who makes a mockery of the statistics. I feel too that we are faced with the knowledge that the previous months may have been as good as it gets....what if from now onwards, we have only progression and problems? So it really is an impossible situation to rationalise-be glad to have survived, hope to have as many more as progression allows you. But I don't think we can really celebrate a stage 1V diagnosis-no matter how long we may survive. Hope the anguish passes soon.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 08:44AM ElaineD wrote: The surgery is surprisingly easy. I had it done on the Thursday, and was home Saturday morning-and helping to prepare Sunday lunch a few hours later. I had  very little pain and discomfort both times (had them done seperately).With some preparetion in advance, you will find that you need little help for practicalities-but may appreciate the emotional support. But, do you really want to subject yourself to surgery at this stage-I'm a great believer in making life as tolerable as possible for ourselves, and with no definite advantage apparent to overall survival, I would proceed with caution. You may-like me-be lucky, post surgery. Or you may, have problems, which wouldn't be good. Oh-and I later developed lymphoedema which wouldn't otherwise have happened-and that really is limiting and tiresome. Good luck with your decision.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 12:21PM ElaineD wrote: No regrets. I feel that my life has been incredibly blessed. I met the love of my life when we were 15 and at school together. We parted, and then found each other again. Sometimes I feel that I wish I had done more with my education (I read Spanish and Portuguese at uni)-but in order to do what I would have wanted (translate), I would have needed to have done a second degree-and by that point we were married and couldn't afford it. When we had kids, I opted to stay at home, and do voluntary work/fund raising-and even when the kids were older, I was perfectly content with my lifestyle. Granted there was no financial pressure for me to return to work-I guess if there had been, I may have gone along a different route. My only regrets are for the future. We are now in our 50s, and are at the satge of feeling that perhaps Brian should retire early-so we can do the things we had planned in 10 years or so without further delay. I'm racked (wracked?) with guilt that he is contemplating giving up a career which he loves-all because of my ill health. But regrets-nope, I'd do it all again!

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2009 04:33AM ElaineD wrote: The other surgery which is recommended is removal of the ovaries-so this would impact perhaps on when you would have a family. For example, one of my younger cousins who also has the misprint, decided to have one more child, and then go ahead with preventative surgery. It possibly didn't make a huge deal of difference to her timing-but she admits she might have left it for another few years, had she not tested positive. Our daughter, who is now 26 (and getting married in March!), has accepted that if she has children, then she would be wise to do it by mid 30s. Surgery is generally recommended, late30s-early 40s, when the risk increases significantly. I strongly recommend you at least talk to a geneticist, and have the risk factors explained to you. There's a huge amount to take on board, and this would be an excellent first step in helping you decide whether or not to proceed. You sound very sensible, so I'm sure you'll work your way through this nightmare.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2010 10:24AM ElaineD wrote: I've just read an early post from you where you said that you were convinced her treatment was working, and that no progression would be found. So of course, having gone from one extreme, to another,it's inevitable that you are confused. Herein lies the danger of being too upbeat, unfortunately-when we get bad news, and have been expecting good news, the shock to our systems is huge. So-you have learned one very valuable lesson already-you can take nothing for granted, there are no guarantees that treatement will be succesful-and most importantly, keeping a grip on the reality and the enormity of the situation is vital.Perhaps the next treatment will be succesful-but all she can do is try. Adding in herceptin may help-or at the least, even things up slightly-people with hormone receptive tumours may get help from hormonal treatment-those of us with HER2+ may get some advantage from adding herceptin into the mix. But.....a further word of caution! We've found that the herceptin alone is never sufficient to contain the tumours-we can't of course, measure it's efficacy when used alongside a chemo. So, once again I implore you to "hope for the best, but prepare for the worst".....

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2010 06:12PM ElaineD wrote: "Is there a link between the amount of pain and our fears...?" Absolutely. When we hurt, it's only human nature to speculate as to why. Someone who hasn't had cancer would view aches, as aches :we think bone mets. Headaches become brain mets, and a cough is likely to be lung mets! Of course, at times, it will transpire that these aches will have a sinister reason. But more often than not, there will be an innocent explanation. At stage 1V I think our fears are reasonable-if not rational. But what does sadden me is seeing someone with a good prognosis also reacting to every pain-that way, they really are allowing the cancer to gain the upperhand, even if only mentally. Our vulnerability is one of the hardest things we have to deal with, and rationalise-if we can. When I was diagnosed with mets, I had no symptoms whasover-a routine chest xray showed mets to the pleura, and subsequent investigations found mets in the liver and bones. No pain, no symptoms-and yet there have been times when I have suffered quite intense pain-yet no progression. I feel that after so long of treatment (2.5 years for me), my body is weak, even although my spirit is willing-and perhaps I just can't cope with pain as well as I used to do. It's also quite exhausting too, which only adds to the worry. "I'm in pain, and I feel tired, I must have progression"!!!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 10:36AM ElaineD wrote: You may manage to get short breaks, if your condition can be stabilised-or you can reach NED. At the moment, for example, I am only on pamidronate and herceptin, haveing completed a course of carboplatin in May. Recent increases in pain levels would suggest we have further progression, so I'm fully expecting to resume chemo again after the next CT which is due the middle of next month. I'm surprised that your onc didn't explain this more clearly to you, as it really is such a basic fact of our lives. You may even find that being on active treatment gives you a certain peace of mind, whereas having a break tends to increase the stress levels.You really can't compare prostate and bone cancers to metastatic bc, which by the nature of it has spread to vital organs-in your case, the brain. Being er-/pr- also limits your treatment options to rads and chemo, as hormonal treatments will not be effective on a negative status. Many of us live by the mantra-"hope for the best, but prepare for the worst"-ie, stay as upbeat as you can about what treatment can achieve for you-but accept that you will likely have many upsets and setbacks. I would love to say to you, "you'll be fine"-but that would be incredibly irresponsible of me. Even your onc can't say this,although he will do his best to treat you as effectively as possible, for as long as possible. Good luck with whatever treatments the future holds for you-there are many different chemo types available (although few which cross the blood brain barrier, so this will limit you somewhat).
Posts.Title: Will I Always be "In Treatment"? dharmamama Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2010 08:44AM ElaineD wrote: Lol-since you worked in oncology, how did you not know that you would always be in treatment?! To Lynn-endless chemo just becomes part of our lives-you'll be amazed how quickly you will adjust, and how grateful you will be if you get sufficient stability to enable you to have a break from it. Like so much with cancer, the anticipation of what endless treatment means, can often be a bit worse than the reality of it. Of course it is tough, and time consuming, and often we will feel dreadful. But there can be good times too-especially early on before the cancer itself causes too many problems or pain issues. Enjoy these times-and when you have a bad day, hope that tomorrow will be  a better one. You can do it-if for no reason other than the fact that we have no choice, other than to decline treatment.

Posts.Content: ElaineD wrote: We've been on holiday for 2 weks, arriving back home at lunchtime today, and a few hours later, my consultant was on the phone giving me the results from the CT scan I had on Tuesday-such is life that we even holiday now closeby to the hospital so we can continue with appointments. There are a lot of tests/monitoring going on at present, as I'm on phase 2 of a trial for PARP inhibitors, which is being used for BRCA+ cancers. I'm scanned after every 2 cycles, and have been stable in the previous 2 scans-and am stable again today. We've had some slight reduction in the mets to the pleura and chest wall, but an increase in one of the liver mets, which overall equals "stable". There are 12 cycles of treatment in the trial, and I'm hoping that I can remain stable for the duration, and then either increase the dosage, or add in a chemo. But for the meantime, it'll be business as usual on Monday, when cycle 7 begins.Was hugely relieved to hear the result-the pain has been quite severe recently, and I was starting to imagine the worst. But I'm now a bit more confident that the pain is nerve pain, so will be getting some meds for this next week to see if this helps. Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2009 02:10AM ElaineD wrote: Good for you Vivo! But you know with all the progress there is being made in the genetic field, I think you could take comfort form the fact that if you did have children, by the time that they were old enough for any gene misprint to possibly affect them, there's every hope that the experts will have found some way of eradicating it. It all sounds a bit like science fiction at the moment, but it's a field which is bringing huge progress on a regular basis. You commented about the baby born here, and I'm not meaning that level of manipulation/screening (this made me rather uncomfortable if truth be told) . But the hope is that in the future if a gene is passed on, then it can be eliminated. If you want a family soon-then go ahead and do so . There may be little that this generation can do to avoid it at the moment, but subsequent generations will have access to therapies today which will be far reaching. Without wishing to worry you further-don't forget that a potential BRCA mutation is only one of the huge range of genes that we pass on to our children, and realistically we don't spend time worrying about every other potential genetic problem/issue we may pass on. So, you're absolutely right to pursue it further, but please don't let it dominate your thoughts excessively, and enjoy instead your plans for the future!

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2009 05:59PM ElaineD wrote: Vivo, isolated cases from another branch of  a family can't really be added into the equation. Most families have experience of cancer+/or deaths from cancer, as it's such a prevalent disease. The fact that your m.i.l died form BC again  doesn't automatically imply that there is a genetic misprint in the family, as  the vast majority of BC cases are not genetic. The main criteria for suspecting genetic BC are if- 4 relatives from same side(ie, from exclusively either  your Mum or Dad's branch) with BC/ovarian at any age, 3 relatives  from same side, aged under 60 2 relatives from same side under 40 Even factoring in the possible connection from the prostate cancer, you still only have your Mum, and possibly uncle , as a potentially suspicious genetic BC. I feel that you want to pursue this, and in order to give you peace of mind, then it may be worth putting this into motion asap. But please try not to worry excessively. Of course there is a chance that there's a link-can I ask if either of your Mum's parents had BC, as this would clarify the issue slightly. If neither of them did have a BC diagnosis then it's unlikely that a genetic misprint would have been passed onwards from them to your Mum's generation. For this to be the case, then the inference is that they died form other causes, without being aware that they had BC. Not imposssible, but rather unlikley. Just trying to view this dilemna from all angles-am not saying that you shouldn't be concerned and make further enquiries-but as Beesie said, the incidence of cancer in your family is not excessively high. In the meantime, if you can collate as much information as possible, putting into a family tree, then this will help in the original assessment, should you decide to go ahead. Good luck-and hoping that any tests return negative. Best wishes too, to your Mum at this tough time for her..just one final thought (sorry!). If your Mum is undergoing treatment at present, this type of testing might be quite upsetting for her at the moment, so waiting for a few months might be an idea?

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 05:45AM ElaineD wrote: Not at all! What you are actually doing is moving on. Soon you will find that you don't even ask yourself these questions very often-and you'll just get on with enjoying your life. Check up time will come around-you'll get stressed (everyone does), aches and pains will be  worry for a while. But then you'll realise that having had cancer doesn't stop you getting aches and pains! I was diagnosed with primaries, back in 1996, and mets in 2007. At this stage it really is a case of trial and error to see what treatments may keep our disease under control for as long as possible. As a Mum, my main focus is to attempt to impact as little as possible on my chidrens' lives-I think most Mums feel the same. Perhaps visiting as often as you can manage-but without suddenly running back to her too often, would be the best way forward.If you suddenly start to visit lots more than usual, you may unintentionally give her the message that you think you will lose her soon. Be honest with her-tell her you are frightened and concerned and want to help as much as possible-my kids did this, and it gave me the chance to reassure them that I wouldn't hesitate to ask for help when/if I needed it. This was comforting to us all. Does she have any other family closer? How old is she-you said she was weak-is she coping with the practicalities of daily life, as well as the treatment? It could be that you could investigate some practical help for her if necessary, and this too will give you additional peace of mind-knowing that she has help, even if it can't always be you doing the helping, will be good for you. I really sympathise with your situation-so many of us here feel that it's worse for our families, and loved ones than it is for us. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 05:34AM ElaineD wrote: I'm sure we all have our "pet" theories as to what is going to one day lead to a cure-or at the very least, better/more effective treatment. I'm personally very keen on targetted therapies for genetic bcs for example. However, I don't expect everyone to share my passions and enthusiasms. I've read about the vaccines-and am far from convinced that this is the way forward-it's too simplistic a solution for this type of multi faceted disease, for one reason. I think we have to bow to the inevitable-there is lots of ongoing research, and not enough money to fund it. I've said it so often-I really wish with all my heart that we had an "expert" on bcorg who could realistically interpret data for us, thereby saving ourselves false hope over trials which promise miracles.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 11:31AM ElaineD wrote: Looking at it from a slightly different slant. Do we hope/expect those around us to always get it right, and never say the wrong things? Realistically, that isn't going to happen.They have their own fears and worries too, and I guess they sometimes will lash out at us (and I don't mean physically, just saying the wrong things). Having cancer hasn't turned us into perfect creatures-nor can we expect our partners to be perfect either. I am very blessed with my husband. We've been together since we were 15 and so have grown and changed together. He is the most placid, kind, gentle man you could hope to meet, but I can see the fear and frustration in his eyes. All of our longer term dreams have been wrecked, and I honestly wouldn't blame him if he lost patience with all this entails at times. Unkind words are not pleasant-but let's try and keep a sense of perspective. I'm not sure that I would be able to be a model of kindness 24/7, if hubby was ill, and I was supporting him. At the moment, we are managing just fine, but I feel immensely guilty at having to rely on him more and more. Perhaps it's just me, but I would prefer to be treated as "normally" as possible, for as long as possible, and not have family tip toe around me, fearful of sayng the wrong thing at the wrong time.

Posts.Content: ElaineD wrote: I've been itching to share this news with you for several months. Brian and I have been discussing the possibility of him taking early retirement : the decision is now made, and it's full steam ahead! On the downside, I feel guilty-he loves his job, and the only reason he is retiring is because of my health. At the moment I am coping, but at some stage I will need progressively more help-and he is adamant that he will be the one to do so. It seems such a huge shame that he has to take such a drastic step, but he assures me that it's what he wants. On the plus side, it's financially very viable for us. All along we have paid extra into his pension fund (we have been in a position for him to retire since he was 50, and he‘s now 54!), and his pension is extremely generous, so we have no worries on that score. He is giving 3 months notice, so provisionally our big adventure is due to begin on 31st March. It's heartbreaking that we are doing this-but we are realistic enough to accept that if we want to have any time as retirees, it has to be sooner rather than later. It breaks my heart to know that we won't grow old together, but I'm determined that we should have as long as possible with that type of lifestyle. At the moment we have no plans to travel- no doubt we will have a few holidays along the way, but think we have to get used to a new lifestyle as soon as possible. One of the first things we will do is downsize to a smaller house-hopefully one which has a workshop attached, or one which we can add a workshop to in due course. One of his hobbies is restoring old sports cars, so this could become virtually a self-financing hobby and small business for him in years to come. At present we are in a townhouse-and the 3rd floor is rarely used, so downsizing makes sense. Please don't think me morbid, but I'm also thinking on to a time when I am no longer here so if we can get Brian installed in a house more suited to his needs, and one in which we have had some time together, then it may make life marginally easier for him. It would simply break my heart to think of him having to do this alone at some point in the future, so this will be our first priority. He'll continue having some contact with work, as he'll be kept on as a (non-executive) director. In time he may also be used by them on an ad hoc basis as a consultant. But, in the short term, the focus will be exclusively on ourselves! All in all we're thrilled and excited to have finally made a decision. The kids are excited for us, and both said the same to him when he phoned them earlier-"nobody deserves it more" They have seen how hard Brian has worked over the years, and how focused and dedicated he is, so I have to say, I completely agree with them. Exciting times ahead for the clan-watch this space! Dx 11/4/2007, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 06:08PM ElaineD wrote: I'm actually thinking about taking a break from the site for a while. It's good to try to help and support, but there also seems to be a lot of anger around at the moment, and I find that harder to deal with. Am I the only one who has moved on from being angry at there being no cure for cancer? It saddnes and hurts me immensely-but I won't waste my precious energy in getting angry at it. We've seen threads in the past blaming medics, pharmaceutical companies, governments for colluding in there being no cure. Maybe it's far more simple-it's too sneaky a range of diseases to respond well to any treatment for any length of time. I want to save my precious energies for doing good and positive things (I make no apology for using the word "positive"-where are we without a dogmatic attitude to survival-and again, I won't get tied up in the semantics used) I feel huge hurt that we lose so many sisters so regularly-but anger just seems counterproductive and creates a tension which is difficult to handle. Maybe this is my little bit of living in denial-but I will no longer do anger over things that can't be changed. Doing so is letting cancer win yet another battle. So yes, I too alternate between wanting to be here, and considering spending less time online.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2010 05:24AM ElaineD wrote: What a lovely post! "Stable " is good.....a bit like winning the silver medal, rather than the gold! Thank you too, for your kind words-am just so glad that you feel I'm able to help in some small way, as so often I feel completely helpless......I try to be honest, without being frightening, and just share little tips that have helped me in some way. I had to refocus myself on the "as good as it gets" last night! I had chemo yesterday (pamidronate, herceptin, and cycle 3 of navelbine). I've been a bit despondent, thinking that the navelbine isn't working, as the pain seems to be increasing (more so on the right, which is a new development) Part of me hopes that it may be tumour flare-but experience has taught me that it is more usually caused by progression. Scans are due in a few weeks, so all will be revealed... Anyhow, decided to go to bed early-about 9pm, and noticed that my right arm and hand were swollen, and red (I used to have lymphoedema on this side). Our system here is that until 6pm we phone the day unit for advise:between 6pm-8am, we phone the oncology ward. On no account do they want us going to A+E ("accident and emergency")! So, I phoned-to be told to come in immediatley with an overnight bag, for good measure. We arrived at 10pm, and a lovely nurse took bloods, and returned regulary to reasure us that doctor would be here soon. By 3.30am we gave up and returned home-not having seen a doc! The nurse was very apologetic-and it was not her fault, but am livid at the doc, as one of the concerns was that it could be  p.e. They were meant to phone and check on me this morning-but nothing so far! So, I'm exercising my mantra of taking a day at a time, and trying not to stress too much!

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 10:15AM ElaineD wrote: As Elizabeth has said, we cannot hope for a cure. But we do hope to stay as stable as possible, for as long as possible. Your onc is right-it will escalate, to the point where you will need to be on chemo continuously-if lucky we sometimes get short breaks to allow our bodies to recover some strength, and give us a rest from the endless side effects. It's  hard thing to accept-but if you can work at accepting and understanding this basic fact, you will find living with the disease can be manageable for periods of time. Sooner or later the treatments cease to be effective-our bodies become immune to the drugs (a frighteneing thought!), which is why your onc expects your symptoms to worsten. However, there are a number of chemos which can be tried-some work well for some of us-some don't help at all. It really is just  a case of trial and error to try and establish what can help us.
Posts.Title: Stage IV-Can you go into remission, or be cured? amontro Landerson3237

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 01:46PM ElaineD wrote: So sorry to hear of the additional stress caused by your boyfriend. Whilst changes should be carefully thought through, it does sound as if this issue needs to be addressed quickly. You have to be kind to yourself, and keep as well as possible-both physically and mentally. Whilst stress may not aggravate/cause cancer (I don't think anyone knows for sure)-it certainly doesn't help us to deal with the problems we face on a daily basis. Please don't think "the end is near"-not even your onc can know that for sure. But it's important to have as much control/peace in our life as we can-there are so many areas in our lives now where we have little or no control. As I said, no 2 people repond the same to treatment-so it's hard for us to say, "you'll be fine"-we simply don't know how you'll thrive. But take comfort from the fact that there is no reason not to hope that you will find a chemo which will help when it becomes necessary. But, before that time, I hope you have this relationship problem resolved-good luck.

My blood is boiling at these repeated claims at diet/lifestyle "curing" cancer (they appear regularly on the forum). If anyone wants to risk their lives by going along with it-fine, that is their choice. But please don't encourage vulnerable and frightened people to dice with death, by leading them to think that eating copious amounts of broccoli-or whatever-will help them. Cancer is a sneaky and devious beast-please don't assume that it will have an easy solution.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 08:40AM ElaineD wrote: No apology necessary, as your thread wasn't the one!A while ago there were several threads which were being bumped every few hours, and I think they ended up being removed because of the aggravation they were causing. This went far beyond posting info for helping-it rather bordered on an obsessive desire to wind up support for the poster's pet cause, and became tedious. I'm all in favour of new developments being shared here-they may not be of help to us, but perhaps may help our children/grandchildren-and that alone is casue for hope. We all do what we feel is best-but I do think we need to proceed with caution-we are not experts when all is said and done. I think there's a fine line between hope and denial-and trying to stay on the right side of it is difficult, if not impossible. I guess it's just in my psyche to be as realistic as possible as to my/our situations. I've had a few chemos fail me, and the devastation that alone can cause has further underlined, for me at last, that a  realistic acceptance of the limitation the treatments have at present is actually less stressfuul than expecting superb results-and then being heartbroken if they don't materialise. I'm one who would happily settle for stable disease-perhaps I just don't aim high enough? (A form of self protection from disappointment, methinks....)

Might the friend be upset at your sister for sharing her news? Many of us at initial diagnosis want as few people as possiible to know-and a friend's sister,may not be high on her list of people who need to know.Talking with strangers-no matter how good their intentions-can be hard. However, should she contact you, then that would be quite different.Please don't take this the wrong way, but a stage 1V diagnosis is completely different, and I don't know how much understanding/knowledge you would have of what we face on a daily basis. Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 09:52AM ElaineD wrote: At times, limiting the amount of time you spend on the forum is a good thing. It's so easy to start googling, searching for information-and then not liking the answers found! So, limiting the amount of information you take on board can be a very positive thing to do-don't burden yourself with more than you can deal with at any moment in time. Having said that, there is always someone available to help/advise if you are feeling low, or have any questions. Try not to look to far into the future. I'm not too keen on the "cancer sucks" phrase-cancer does so much more than that, and it feels a bit like stating the obvious. I prefer to think of it as a cruel beast, which follows no logic, and has no compassion whatsoever. Again, you can turn this to your advantage-because there is no logic to the way it develops/spreads, you can reasonably safely assume that it is by no means guaranteed that because your mets were there for a while, that you will have rapid deterioration. Truth to tell, is that there is simply no way of knowing who will do well on treatement, and who will not. All we can do is try as hard as we are able for as long as we are able-a horrendous load for anyone to have to carry.You have as much chance as the rest of us of responding favourably to treatment-and I wish you well in this. As I keep saying...."hope for the best, but prepare for the worst",x

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 07:20PM ElaineD wrote: An occasional night/day without wearing the garments is fine. My fear was that if I did it occasionally, then I might be tempted to do so more regularly, so I just soldiered on. But if you can be disciplined about it, then I don't think an occasional day would make much difference. Incidentally, I didn't wear mine 24/7-I always took them off at bedtime-it felt blissful when they came off! I have no idea if you wear rings on that hand, but if you do, it would be good to take them off for a while. It can be surprising how quickly the fingers can swell, and the last thing you need is to have a ring you can't get off. Am speaking from personal experience on that one too! I don't know how well informed the medics are with you, but over here most aren't terribly knowledgeable about lymphodema, and even now I sometimes have to explain why they may not use my bad arm for bloods or b.p readings! I also carry  a card in my purse to alert hospital staff if I'm unconscious. Be extra vigilant about scratches-they can quickly let infection in, resulting in cellulitis which can be very painful and unpleasant. It responds well to antibiotics- but any excessive redness and tenderness may indicate the onset of cellulitis, so watch out for that. Am painting a pretty horrific picture of it all-sorry! But it's actually all very manageable, and if your therapist feels that it should be possible to get it under control, then that's a great thing to focus on.
Posts.Title: Feeling a little Depressed...Mild Le. lexislove Suzybelle

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 04:19AM ElaineD wrote: Sorry to hear about your rings. But I made the mistake of not removing mine quickly enough-and it needed to be cut off. Now that was hugey distressing, and broke my heart. We had it remade (I refused to get a new one), and wore it on a chain around my neck). So really, although it's upsetting not to wear them, the alternatives of risking wearing them for as long as possible, can be even worse.They're now back where they belong, on my finger-and have been for a while. That for me was the true sign that the lymphoedema was controlled. Re the gloves at work-could you wear latex over the garment? You'll need a bigger size than usual, but this should be ok. I used to use those when I was working around the house or gardening. But as to washing your hands regularly-that really is more tricky...

Posts.Title: curing yourself lukejessesmom ElaineD

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 10:55PM ElaineD wrote: I'm so glad that already we have helped, by helping you uderstand the difference in the staging. Really, it's something that the vast majority of patients have no idea about, until such time as they need to know for one reason or another. And why should they-after  a primary diagnosis, it's good and proper to try to move on,not let the cancer experience dominate life and thoughts. But you clearly have a good understanding of all this involves, which means that you can perhaps help much more than you think. I had a somewhat similair experience-in reverse-yesterday, which might help you. I was having my chemo+herceptin, and got chatting to the girl next to me. She was clearly a primary patient-for some reason, primary/secondary patients are treateted at the same time. Anyhow, I'm always a bit reluctant to give my details, without prefixing it all with "you might not like what I have to say". However, she was interested, had a good degree of understanding that our situations were very, very different (she opted to have chemo, despite being told that it would make little difference to her prognosis). She fels that she has to do everything possible to ensure a cancer free future, and I respect her enormously for this. So I shared my history : she was upset for me, wished me well, hoped I didn't brood on stastics, and hoped too that I was able to enjoy each day for what it was. Well, this confirmed that although our situations are diametrically opposed, we had a huge amount in common. As we're on the same 3 weekly cycle, she suggested we meet up next time beforehand, either for lunch or coffee! I was thrilled. We asked to have our appointments as close together as possible, so we've been given the same time. So, we're meeting an hour beforehand for a coffee, and then going down for our treatment. The nurses even asked if we wanted to sit together again..."yes please," came the reply in unison! Sorry for my ramble-but I think it shows that it is possible to be supportive. After all, it's what many of our friends and family are doing without any cancer experience whatsoever. Your experiences will have given you insight into many of the treatments and s/effects-and that alone could be helpful for her. Of course, so much will depend on how much or little she wants-but maybe even the fact of you being long distance could be a good point for her. Who knows-but think so far, as I said, you've done things just right....
Posts.Title: How do I deal with this???? scrappy_survivor noblegases

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2010 12:47PM ElaineD wrote: I know she has asked for this-but could you consider doing it after the surgery? This could be as soon as the following weekend, as the stay in hospital is only a few days.The thought of a gathering beforehand strikes me as a bit morbid-sorry! It'll be a tense time, when things could so easily go wrong, or things said which could be upsetting. The potential is for it to do more harm than good. Has she said why she wants to do this? A get together afterwards, on the other hand, could be more relaxing. I had my first mastectomy on a Thursday, and was helping prepare lunch on the Sunday-so recovery time is usually quick. I'm at a loss to suggest what to do-from personal experience, I wanted no fuss beforehand,but was glad of company and support afterwards.I wish you well-but have reservations about her request!

Posts.Title: Early Detection of Mets- Does it Matter? TripleNeg RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 08:55AM ElaineD wrote: Tupelo has summed it up perfectly. I queitly celebrated passing 5 years....then 10 years. I began to feel confident that I may be one of the lucky ones-and back it came, 13 years later. I am now stage 1V and therefore terminal-and this is despite doing everything recommended, and even having prophylactic surgery as I'm BRCA2. I would suggest that it's actually less devastating in the long term, to always have the possibility of recurrence in the back of your mind-just try to keep it in the back of your mind, and don't become paranoid about every pain! As I had started to believe I was going to be ok, the resultant shock when I was diagnosed with recurrence was undescribably awful. I couldn't assimilate it at all. Spent 4 days looking at the wall and crying, unable to move. Had I kept the possibility of recurrence in my mind, I think I may have found the shock of diagnosis easier to bear. I'll never know, but it sounds logical. I had even suggested to my onc that we could dispense with annual checkups-that was in the August-I was rediagnosed in the November! Talk about timing.....Good luck to you all-hope with all my heart that none of you ever end up in my situation.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 02:53AM ElaineD wrote: Good luck with the consultation. Don't feel you need answers to everything immediately. Sadly your friend will be on treatment of some kind for the rest of her life,so you all have time to get to learn about what will be necessary, and when. I keep advising people to take a step at a time-it helps make it all that little bit more manageable. Don't be surprised if your friend changes-even temporarily. She may become angry, and want some time on her own-this doesn't mean she's rejecting you, just that she and her family need to come to terms with this life changing event. Try and treat her as normally as possible-she's not suddenly become an invalid who needs nursing! But at the same time, she may (or may not), be glad to be cossetted. Perhaps it would also help your friend if you suggested she join us here? There's lots of information-and a huge amount of support-so it may be helpful for her to chat to us, are we are all experiencing similair problems.Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 01:05AM ElaineD wrote: I've just started a PARP trial-I really should start a thread about it! Anyhow, I've had my first treatment, found it all quite manageable, although I had the nausea/exhaustion-and surprisingly, perhaps, the pain levels absolutely rocketed. I felt quite poorly for the week of the infusions,and three days afterwards, but am starting to feel much better now. I'm BRCA2, so this is an exciting development for me. The plan is ultimately (if it works), to introduce a chemo at some point-when the tumours have become more vulnerable to treatment. Obviously we are all a bit in the dark as to what to expect (I'm only the 3rd person in the U.K to have this drug, so there's little information as yet.) What has upset me-is the criticcal comments I have received-"it's just another hyped up drug, that likley won't work", "you must be mad", etc etc.....Why can't people be more supportive-OH and I decided it was worth a shot, so can't that be respected? I still have conventional chemo options available to me, and I'll be back on them at some point. But for now we wanted to try this-I'm not expecting miraculous results-and in fact, I was as much motivated to try it in the hope of moving the research along a little. So many of my family have now ben diagnosed with the BRCA2 misprint, that perhaps if this in the long term does yield some benefits to future generations, then my very small contribution can be part of my legacy to my family... Anyhow, think I have a few seperate threads on these subjects, so I'll be back later!

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 07:33AM ElaineD wrote: Not sure why we want to be sidetracked into a discussion about diabetes-this was not the question posed! I don't expect we will see a cure for BC in our lifetimes-but have every hope that subsequent generations will have a cure available-maybe in 20 years or so? This is what gives me hope, and is the motivating factor to why I plan to participate in as many trials as possible. If I can get some benefit from trials-that's a bonus, but not my prime motivation. A  cure, even if well adavanced at this moment in time, would be too late for any of us, I suspect. I see that Baseball fan is one of the few proponents of the bc vaccine, and may be becoming disillusioned with all the hype surrounding it-thereby the question.(which, incidentally I think Susan answered perfectly.)? I must admit to getting frustrated at reading posts which hold out over hyped promise-we must take care to be realistic in our enthusiaisms, otherwise people cling to a false hope which won't/can't materialise. This may be great in the short term-but when reality sets in (and we accept that 6 mice responding to a vaccine doesn't equal a cure for bc!!!), then the disappointment is even more profound. I feel particulary for newbies when we hold out these "miracles" rather than helping them towards acceptance of the limitations of the treatments we have available at this moment in time. Hope is great-of course it is-but we also need to be realistic in our expectations. Not sure either if the original question was really asking what our oncs think-for the record, mine does not think a cure is even close-but that tragetted treatments might provide part fo the answer.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 06:41PM ElaineD wrote: Why would you want to entertain "gloom and doom" if you were happy being positive? This is what I don't understand, and why I am concerned. Many of us try to live our lives as best we can, and make the most of what little time we have on this earth. Why you felt that this ostracised you is a mystery. I query the fact that you feel that we "dwell on ourselves". I have found this forum to be endlessly supportive, and genuinely helpful to people who have final stage cancer. But-it is a forum, and people are welcome to share their views-provided of course, that it's understood that you may find opinions different to your own-such is the nature of forums. Your original post said- " I was just thinking, we all talk about our sickness and it gives energy to it.I  am quite a happy person, and quietly realized I couldn't stop this disease by talking about it, so I go about my life laughing and enjoying everything, good and bad, Then I come in here and find myself in tears, and depression all night. Why don,t we get together and instead of talking sickness, talk about what we have in common, that may have caused us to get this." Common denominator " Granted this was not received well-but nobody was unpleasant to you-they merely made suggestions as to how you could find something that met your needs. I find this latest post, which contradicts your original,very sad. We can all have times of experiencing both  despair and horror at our situation-but we try to pick ourselves up and start the new day afresh. I'm simply astounded that you have veered towards "gloom and doom" simply because you were hurt that a post you made wasn't well received. Cancer is the enemy here-not your fellow sufferers.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 10:08AM ElaineD wrote: Elizabeth, I'm another who doesn't cry a lot. I guess it's not obligatory to do so. I wonder if we are simply more accepting about what life has thrown our way? I don't do "anger" with the cancer either. Lots of people have incredibly hard lives-we do too, but so do many people for other reasons-often not cancer related. I try my best just to get on with it-avoid excessive introspection, and just take a day at a time. I accept that I'll die a premature death-from cancer, unless there's a strange twist of fate in my life. None of these things make me bitter-sad, very, very sad, but bitter or tearful? No. I too often get the "you're so strong/brave". As an aside-these comments don't offend-people are struggling to find the right thing to say-cancer has us struggling for words, why should our friends be any different, or suddenly develop into semantic superstars forever saying the right things (if there is such a thing...) If this is your way of coping/surviving, then stick with it-we're all different in our coping mechanisms.

Posts.Title: curing yourself lukejessesmom ElaineD

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 06:34PM ElaineD wrote: I don't know if this will comfort you or not-but here's my experience. I too had relatively mild lymphoedema, and it lasted several years. I'm a stubborn sort, and decided that I would persevere in an attempt to get it as under control as possible. It took  a long time-literally years, of wearing the garments, all day every day. But slowly it did get better-to the extent now that my arm is now "normal" in appearance, and I no longer need the garments. I still monitor it closely-surprisingly for me, I tended to react more to cold than heat, so am always particularly careful to wear gloves in colder weather. It could be that you will get your's back under control much quicker than I did-I hope so! But it is worth persevering for as long as it takes-eventually you will succeed. I can understand your sadness-it is a visible reminder of what has happened to you. Bizarrely, I had more questions from people about my bandages than I did about my body shape (I had had a mastectomy by that point, and didn't have reconstruction, nor use prosthesis) But they do work-and along with massage sessions, you may find the swelling goes down quite soon. Don't expect too much too soon-and please wear the garments as much as you can-they really do work. After a while you won't even notice they are there. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 06:56PM ElaineD wrote: After a while, the looks didn't bother me-although it took a bit of getting used to. The questions were harder-so many people seemed to think I'd had an accident. Very few people (by this I mean strangers) pushed me for an answer,although I had a few who tried. One sticks in mind  -I had tried to evade giving too much detail, but this guy kept on at me-so I eventually just said "it's a side effect to surgery for b.c"-and that shut him up. I should say that this was a complete stranger in a bookshop! More often than not, if asked what the bandages were for, I would say, "you really don't want to know-it's a very long story" (emphasising the "very") Do you know, the vast majority of people were happy with that answer! Initially you will feel self-conscious, but it will pass-just keep reminding yourself why you're doing it. Incidentally, they are not in the slightest uncomfortable to wear. I often had friends and family asking if I was too hot wearing them-but they don't make you sweat-another reason why it was so easy to persevere wearing them. I did however get some tender spots-mainly between my thumb and first finger, and the elbow too got quite itchy at times. Sssh, don't tell, but I used to do the cardinal sin of scratching these areas to get some relief-well, it was more of a gentle rub, but it helped!

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 04:25AM ElaineD wrote: Diclofenac is excellent Stephanie.....but!! (Didn't you just know there would be a but!) Do watch out for your bowel-it caused regular constipation for me, which I wasn't pro-active enough in dealing with, and this made my diverticular disease worse.It would have been easy enough to have dealt with this, had I been more "aware", so keep your eye on it. I was also taking it regularly, as it was so effective in dealing with shoulder pain. But, I found I became very reliant on it, and had quite a lot of difficulty coming off it! I wasn't exactly hooked, but needed to wean myself off it gradually. But, for me it proved to be very effective, for a long time indeed, and I'm so pleased that you're finding it useful-and more importantly, had a good session with the pain management specialist.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 01:54PM ElaineD wrote: It would be wrong to speculate as to what the issue is here. Do remember that most lumps are benign-especially at your age. However, it's wise to have this investigated thoroughly at this stage, so you are doing all the right things. In the same way, it would be wrong for the doc to speculate-what if she reassured you that she was 90% certain that all was well-and it transpired there was a problem? Your devastation would be even worse. Conversely, she can't suggest that the likelihood is that it will be cancer-only a biopsy will determine this. You are at the worst stage at this moment in time-knowing something needs investigated, but not knowing if it's serious. Wishing you all good luck imaginable, and hope with all my heart you have a benign result. Incidentally, family history with bc not only means first degree relatives who have had bc at an early age, Some of the male cancers-prostate, for example, are also implicated. Do you have any relatives who would fall into this category?

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2011 10:34AM ElaineD wrote: Guess I'm in the minority here-I don't want special treatmnet. It strikes me we can't have it both ways. So often when newbies introduce themselves, many rush to reasssure them that they have "a chronic condition which can be managed". By and large this may be true if you are limited to having bone mets-but with further organ involvement, we can't really say this is the case for more than a very few people.Is it fair, in that case, therefore to expect any more special treatment than those suffering from diabetes/heart disaese/manageable conditions? So there I see a dilemna-I personally want to be treated as normally as possible for as long as possible-hard when it's obvious that I am ill (archetypal cancer patient-bald and thin), so people can guess by looking at me what my problem may be.But special treatment-why? Many also suffer from other serious medical and life ending illnesses too-there would be a lot needing special treatment if this requirement  qualified one for it!

So, so, good though, to see him getting on with his life-we're proud of him. But it's still a bit sad when they fly the nest. Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 09:00AM ElaineD wrote: I've had a talc procedure similair to the one LuAnn mentioned, although it wasn't quite so dramatic! It was done under a general anaesthetic,and we had no idea beforehand if it would be succesful, or if they would have to opt for a permanent drain. However, whilst in theatre they do various tests to see how well the talc is adhering, and if succesful, then afterwards all that was necessary was for me to stay in for a few days (no turning necessary!) I had this done last November-the relief was immediate, and so far the fluid hasn't built up again to any great degree.I guess you have to weigh up the potential benefits of this against a delay in starting chemo. Decisions are never easy, are they....I should say though, that Im based in the UK, and I'm progressively noticing the differences in treatments-this being a good example. After the surgery, I would say that the pain was quite minimal, and didn't need much in the way of pain relief in the days afterwards. I wonder if you could ask to have the procedure done in this way? But, good luck and hugs to you both-hoping that the scan results bring some good news.
Posts.Title: Will it get any better? Hopeful101 ElaineD

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 04:24PM ElaineD wrote: Lol-this has made me smile and laugh so much! Perhaps not the initial aim of the poster-but it's great that it's achieved a double whammy. Going to keep a few of them in mind for future use-especially Terry's "I'm fine, not dead yet" Will be seeing my onc next week, so will try it out on him first. But seriously, some good points have been raised here, so thanks to Deb for addressing it. I must admit, what makes me want to rant even more are the posts which look for reassurance that all will be well/the poster won't have a recurrence. How on earth can we possibly give that type of reassurance? It's like attempting to promise that the sun won't rise tomorrow. We none of us know, and I can't grasp how reassuring sufferers that they will be ok is actually doing them any favours.Trying to suggest they learn to accept  uncertainties and fears, live in the present as far as practical, may be kinder advise to give. Cancer-at whatever stage-changes your life forever-returning to pre-life diagnosis may not ever happen, however hard we wish that it would.
Posts.Title: RESPECTING the STAGE threads **RANT** cherneski Nico1012

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 04:04AM ElaineD wrote: Do you know girls, the thoughts and sentiments-and reactions-are so similair to those we have experienced on stage 1V. So often we have had to ask for respect, and to be allowed a safe haven for our thoughts and fears, so I do empathise hugely with your frustrations.We too have been accused of being cliqueish-and perhaps we are, up to a point-but only because we really don't want anyone to be in our shoes. We are at the beginning of the end of our treatments, and this brings about a whole series of fear and events which nobody can possibly understand unless they are facing similair problems. If that classes us as cliquish, then it's only because we are desperately hoping that none of you ever need to find a place amongst us.  I have to agree with Otter's excellent last post-of course it matters what stage we are! How naive it is to think otherwise-perhaps there is more than a little over dramatisation of the severity of an early diagnosis at times, which strikes me as sad.Not so long ago, we had someone post on the palliative board, asking about forgoing treatment-and this was before she was even diagnosed! Completely inappropriate, and unnecessarily cruel to those of us who will need to take this step at some point. So yes, the segregation of stages can be useful-but more importantly, as so many have said-courtesy and respect are paramount. Sadly when struggling with the mental and physical traumas this disease brings our way, sometimes commonsense flies out the window. Incidentally I'm another "active topics" user-but perhaps it really is time to remove this function, if it's causing more harm than good. Best wishes to one and all-whatever your stage. But please-if you're at a stage less than 1V, don't try to advise me. If you're at a stage less than 3, then you may not be able to help the stage 3 girls too much either.

I go down and make a hot choc, then go and wrap up in a blanket in the lounge and read.....I figure that if I drop off to sleep there, it's a bonus, and if I don't then at least it's doing no harm. I don't go back to bed until I get to the stage ("if I get to the stage"), of feeling really sleepy, as I know that my hubby sleeps with one ear awake, so he can help if necessary. But there's no need for both of us to have disturbed nights, so I take myself off rather than try to read in bed. It's far from ideal. But eventually I do manage to return to a better sleeping pattern-if only for a few days/weeks. I realise that this isn't the answer-and may not be any use to you-but it beats tossing and turning in bed, which I find tends to make me even more awake.

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 03:21AM ElaineD wrote: Actually, I've only been on two chemos. But the entrance criteria to the trial stipulated that I had to have had less than three chemos, so it was now or never. I used to think that drug trials would be the last thing I would do-ie, try them only once I'd used up all the chemo options-but it's not quite as straightforward as that. At stage 1V, you will require treatment of one form or another for the rest of your life. You may be lucky and have periods of stabilty, or NED. So far I have only had this short spell of stabilty-and have never had NED, so have always been on one treatment or another. But stable in my book is good. I didn't respond to hormonals, taxotere and herceptin worked for a short time-but the tumours regrew quickly when we tried herceptin alone. Tykerb and lapatanib had me progress further, with quite a few more new tumours. Once PARP starts to fail me, then I will return to conventional chemo-probably carboplatin and herceptin.

Sorry I'm not saying what you want to hear-but this is such a nasty, sneaky, virulent disease that we need to be prepared as far as possible. As you've seen, deterioration can come about so quickly, no matter how much we hope for that elusive miracle. Please, please don't give her too much of a one sided picture -you are living everyone's worst nightmare, but sometimes cocooning the patient doesn't achieve much. Having said that, if the patient was elderly/confused, then that would be quite different.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2009 04:55AM ElaineD wrote: Sadly no, Julie. Once breast cancer has spread, it will need treatment for the rest of the patient's life. It is possible at times to have periods of ned (no evidence of disease), but it will always return at some stage. The medical teams aim to keep us as stable and symptom free as possible, for as long as possible. Ther are may treatments available, so hopefully she will repond well to one of them. Really the only advise, is to take a step at a time.Don't look too far to the future, as the entire situation is frightening and confusing-just deal with problems when they arise. Everyone reacts differently to treatment, and what works well for one, will not work for others-and vice versa. Gene testing sounds like  a good idea for you-it may be that you would not have  a gene misprint-even if your sister does (in which case you could assume it likley came from your Mum), there is still a 50% chance that you wouldn't have inherited the gene. If you had an answer to this, then at least you would be in a situation to consider having prophylactic surgery, to reduce the risk of developing b.c Very tough times for you and your family-try to go with the flow, and take the lead from what your sister needs and wants. But, don't forget to look after yourself as well-I'm sure most of us with metastatic disease would agree with me when I say that it's as bad for our families, as it is for us as patients. The suffering may be different, but it's nonetheless earth shattering. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Content: ElaineD wrote: And I have no idea what to expect, but as usual, am dreading it. After having to come off the PARP trial,my onc started me on carboplatin+herceptin, and I've now had 3 cycles. With some strange happenings. Firstly, one of the palpable bone mets has disappeared (yippee) It's quite good having such an easy barometer! The pain levels have decreased which is also great (am on no pain medication at all at the moment-was previously on codeine+gabapentin,60mg 3 times a day). Pleased about this too-but the pain is still there-and seems to be covering a wider area. It's almost a heavy feeling, if that makes sense.But very manageable, and certainly not needing meds to cope with it. Of course, my brain focuses on the last thing, and am dreading further progression. Hold my virtual hand gals, and I'll do my best to get some good results for us! Am contemplating asking him to scan me less frequently. I don't get too stressed, but it does make me think about cancer more often than normal. Usually I can go about life perfectly happy and content-until the old scanxiety emerges yet again. On this 3 cycle schedule, I'm either gearing myself up for a scan, stressing over the results (in the UK our oncs always give the results on a face to face consult-no collecting results/phoning for them), so we normally have to wait7-10 days for the results. Or, I'm getting used to what the scans have shown-they really do dictate our lives, don't they-even scanning every 4 cycles would give me a bit of a break. But...let's just get tomorrow out of the way first! Dx 11/4/2007, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Goodness, all we want is some privacy on the 20+ seperate boards that there are-it shouldn't be rocket science to post in the correct one. Or does telling us in advance "how brave, knowledgeable and wonderful" we are, make these postings any more acceptable....... Re Jenny....She's doing quite well. She and Sam are still theoretically "together"-in that they haven't seperated. But it's superficial only, and we feel that they will ultimately seperate. Jen is being open and honest-Sam less so, with few people other than his mother and brother even knowing there is a problem! Jen has decamped into the lounge, where she now sleeps-far from ideal, as you can imagine. Her dear friend moved into the spare bedroom a few months ago, and this is helping her enormously, as it lessens the tension between J+S, and the girls enjoy their time together. Her friend has a 9 month old puppy, so they spend a lot of time walking him, which we feel is good for her-it gets her out and about more than she had been doing, and who doesn't love watching doggy antics?! Jen has also just got a kitten, which she is enjoying (and which fortunately gets on ok with the dog) It's just heartbreaking that her affection is being directed to animals, when she has so much love to give. She's coping better with work, and hopes to be doing a longer week soon-which again we feel will help.....and not just financially!!! No doubt in time, Sam will move on (although they were buying the flat together, Jen has the lion's share as we gave her a large sum towards the deposit)-we are happy to buy out his share, so he can also start a new life. We see little or no hope that they will want to stay together-there are just too many differences in what they want from life. In truth, it appears they never really should have got engaged, let alone married.Heartbreaking for them both.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2009 06:27PM ElaineD wrote: "The hard thing the docs don't scan unless you have symptoms." Ok, let's start the rational process here. Imagine if everyone who had ever had a cancer diagnosis was routinely scanned-what would your preference be? Once a year? The system would grind to a halt. So often we read on the boards about how people get impatient and stresed over having to wait for a diagnostic test-imagine how much worse it would be if there were "routine" tests added to the mix! It's actually neither practical nor desirable-and prettyinpink has explained very well why this is the case. I hope you have no further problems-but if you do ever get a mets diagnosis, then speed of diagnosis is not a major concern, unlike a primary cancer where early detection can be important. Remain vigilant-but don't imagine that every headache=brain tumour, every backache=bone mets, every stomach upset=liver mets, etc.....

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 04:34PM ElaineD wrote: Shana said-"I do every day, and hearing someone say something negative, that makes my hopefulness diminish, especially when someone here says it, can be upsetting or depressing." Therein lies the dilemna, of pondering on the possibilty of mets. It can be hugely dispiriting to hear that despite all treatments, a good prognosis, and every other thing going supposedly well, that mets still happen. It's for these reasons that I often urge non-metsters not to dwell (more than can be helped), on what may or may not happen. We are all so unique, that there is no straightforward equation which can show us how we will fare-and as Shana said, hearing bad news only serves to deflate and cause excessive worry.Please girls-live your lives to the full-hope and expect that cancer has been a dreadful experience that you have dealt with, and which won't return to cause you further problems. You could spend a lot of time worrying, when you could be enjoying life. Conversely, if you continue to worry excessively, and then do have further problems, you'll be filled with regret for the time that you've wasted worrying about what may happen. Plus, cling to the fact that each year new drugs are being found which can help-none of these will take the worry away completely, but may help it stay at a manageable level.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2010 01:20PM ElaineD wrote: Lots of thoughts here!!! Firstly, my experience with xeloda was the same (no help for me at all), and I then embarked on a trial, which held me stable for 6 months, which was fabulous. I too then moved on to carboplatin (with herceptin).Scanned after 3+6 cycles we saw reduction in the liver mets both times, and stability in the pleura. A few weeks ago, we decided to stop at 6 cycles, for the following reasons- 1) My platelets were very low each time and the 3 week cycle invariably became a 4 week cycle. 2) I often read/hear, of oncs "wanting to hit it hard"/"throw everything at it", both on this site, and elsewhere. My onc has a completely different attitude. He aims to use as FEW treatments at possible to gain either a measurable response or maintain stability. The benefits to this being twofold-less poisoning for our compromised systems, and the option of spreading out the treatments for as long as possible. I think of it as "saving" some up for future use. In real terms this may only mean an extra few cycles, or an extra few months, but when the time arrives, I imagine I'll be glad of this leeway. The first reason is easy to understand-it's a harsh chemo for the bone marrow, so a break from it will be welcome. Initially I took some convincing of the second reason, when I was initially diagnosed with mets over 2 years ago.But I accepted it then, and it does make sense. If you can accept the rationale which tells us that even at NED, there will still be clusters somewhere in our system, then it makes this strategy more palatable. Like everyone, I would love to achieve NED-but failing that, having options available which can maintain stability are more than acceptable for me. So, for the meantime, we have stopped at 6 cycles, although the herceptin and pamidronate will continue, and I'll be scanned again next month. So, after that long tale, perhaps you and Olga could consider doing the same? It's fantastic she responded so well, and I can fully understand your desire to squeeze every possible benefit from this particular chemo. But, taking a break from it now, means that she still has the potential of keeping it in reserve for future use, before having to try another chemo, which may or may not be as succesful as carboplatin. Personally, I would take a break. The timing for this is good, and would enable you to enjoy the summer. You're a young family, and these times are important for you. I'm often saddened by seeing people focusing so hard on what the future may bring, for better or worse, that they fail to take advantage of what the present is offering. At the moment Olga feels well, has been through a horrendous few months, so some time recouping her strength, and just enjoying life, sounds like a good plan! Hopefully by next summer, Olga will be as well as she is now-in which case you can have another fun filled summer. But if she is in need of treatment at that point, then you will have the comfort of knowing that the summer of 2010 was filled with fun. Please consider taking advantage of this wonderful turn of events-you know more than most, how quickly things can change at stage 1V. You both deserve a break and to have lots of pleasure in your life-both these things are there for the taking, so grab them, if you can, with both hands, and enjoy some quality family time. Sometimes, the short term quality of life, is as important as the longer term aim of controlling the disease as much as possible.... One final thought (hooray, says everyone). I've enjoyed the past few weeks so much, felt overall quite well (painkillers only needed a few times), and have scarcely thought of cancer at all. It's been a huge boon, both physically and mentally, and when I return to treatment, other than that ongoing for the bone mets, I feel it will be with added strength and focus. Good luck with the decision-however you look at it, it's a tough one!

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 10:06PM ElaineD wrote: I'm also BRCA2-much older than you, with 2 children in their 20s! Our daughter (age 24), has been tested, and we know that she too carries the gene. At this age there's little that can be done in terms of monitoring her, but we know what to do if we're concerned-and we know that she'll be prioritised. When I was diagnosed a few years ago with the misprint, we were naturally devastated-butI don't recall ever feeling guilty that I'd passed the gene on-it's not as if I had any choice in the matter! Naturally, we would have preferred it if she's inherited her father's genes on this, but it was not to be. I'm not sure about the situation in the U.S, but testing children here isn't an option until they reach the age of consent (18 here) In all honesty, carry on with your life and plans as before, in terms of having a family. By the time they're older there's every possibilty that the gene misprint can be succesfully manipulated. Genetics is a rapidly developing field, and has made such astonishing progress in the past couple of years, that the possibilty of eradicating the faulty gene in the near future is a real possibilty.
