Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2010 08:53AM ElaineD wrote: I agree with the points that Elizabeth makes. But would also like to add that the liver is notoriously hard to treat. It's not unusual to see some areas responding to treatment, whilst the liver continues to progress. I have had this happen to me several times-regression in pleura, but the liver mets grow. It's incredibly frustrating, but just be grateful that it's having some effect on the other areas. Perhaps in due course anotehr chemo will be added which will tackle the liver mets more succesfully. We are all so different, that there would be no point in making any suggestions as to what may achieve better results-it really is a case of trial and error, forever looking for a chemo which can give us as much benefit as possible-what works for one of us, will be useless for another (as I've found out with xeloda and navelbine, which have been no use to me at all!)

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 12:50PM ElaineD wrote: "When I am struggling against the pain I also get depressed and teary, so I guess for the benefit of myself and my husband I'll give into the meds a little more.  Sometimes 1/2 a pill will do it." How true-it really impacts not just on our ability to cope physically, but also mentally. It's not rocket science, but I know I'm much happier when pain levels are minimal. So it makes it all the more daft to try and be brave/save up the meds for when we really need them. Let's face it, if we don't really need them at stage 1V, when will we! So today, I have taken your advice -as I knew I would. Had the codeine this morning and felt so much better for it-then rather spoiled the effect, by having what seemed to have been a bout of indigestion post lunch! I really wasn't sure what it was at first-in fact, not completely convinced that it may not be my gall bladder starting to protest. We were fence painting, so cheated at lunchtime by sending out for that good old British standby....fish and chips! Sooooo tasty-but so greasy! It was lovely, but I suffered..... Other than that, I'm still feeling not too bad at all-so will take another half dose now, which should keep the pain damped down-and as from tomorrow, will take them on a regular basis. Just one thing that puzzles me though-if we're taking them regularly, how can we judge if we still need them-ie, how do we know if the pain levels improve? (Yep, English Major-that was the holiday countryside-although we were drenched in rain a few times!)

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2009 03:41PM ElaineD wrote: Our kids were 9+11 when I was first diagnosed. It didn't occur to us not to tell them. We simplified it hugely-but even at that age, they have some understanding of cancer. When we started to explain ("Mummy has a lump which needs to be removed, or it will make her very ill")-it was quickly followed by their question "is it cancer?". We protect our kids, but we don't lie to them. They would have been devastated if they had then had worries prompted by things their peer group had said to them. I think it's vital to keep any explanation as simple as possible-but it's important to be honest with them-or at least, in your case, with the eldest. The younger ones may not assimilate too much, but the eldest, as you have seen, has already been put in the situation of being questioned about you by his friends. If you have further problems, he may find it difficult to trust you-however good your intentions of protecting them, I think you have to be honest with them,even if only on a very basic level. Our kids coped with it all very well (mastectomy and chemo), and took great pride in "helping" with jobs around the house. As they were involved, a lot of the potential fear didn't materialise. Then-and now (with mets diagnosed 2 years ago, and kids now in their 20s!), we have always said that we would answer any questions they may have-and if we didn't know the answer, we would do our best to find the answer for them. I honestly think this attitude gave them comfort, focus-and the knowledge that we hadn't lied to them. Given that you have two family members who have had cancer and who are ok, you have a great basis for being able to talk about cancer without it automatically being a chat about cancer=death.

However, as I'm not bleeding as much (was having nose bleeds quite often) this time, it may be that I've recovered slightly better. Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2010 07:25AM ElaineD wrote: Chilli-thank you for the explanation of metronomic chemo-this is something I will certainly be hoping to do at some point. I too have an onc who doesn't believe in hitting it hard-it seems to him (and me), counterproductive to make me even more ill! At stage 1V, even if we attain NED, it will still return anyway-so I much prefer a softer approach. Keep the side effects as minimal as possible, don't blast the liver and bone marrow with too much chemo-otherwise they will give up before we have exhausted all treatment options. I'm much happier with this approach-although accept that it wouldn't suit everyone. I also feel that I want to use treatmnet as sparingly as possible, in the hope that it means that I can stay on active treatment for as long as possible. I would hate to use up all my options too soon, in attempting to attian NED. Stability, a little reduction at times, and as few new tumours as possible, seems an attainable goal for me at this stage., and one which I'm happy to pursue.

Posts.Content: ElaineD wrote: A combinaton of the latest treatment (navelbine), failing, which makes 2 chemos have helped, 2 chemos have failed me-add this to the recent news of our daughter's depression seems to have plunged me into a limbo from which I can't excape. I'm due to start taxol in a  few weeks-so there are still options for me. But my biggest worry is our darling daughter-how long will it take for her to get well? What if I deteriorate very rapidly, before her recovery has taken root-I really don't think she could cope with any more stress in her life in the near future. I'm hoping that soon, my determination to survive for as long as I can will reassert itself-it's one way in which I can help her, so surely that should help focus my thoughts? I seem to waver between being confident, to getting to the depths of despair. The cold weather we've been having for the past few weeks isn't helping-I simply can't cope with it. I'm very slight (about 44 kilos), so don't have the body fat to protect me. Last weekend, when out shopping, the cold seemed to sneak up on me, and it took 4 hours when we got home for me to feel warm again (made me realise how quickly hypothermia can strike). Plus the cold air in my lungs is most uncomfortable. I know there are no answers to any of my (rhetorical) questions-but I swear seeing my daughter suffer is much worse than being given a 1V diagnosis......Having said that, she's had quite a reasonable week-is coping a bit better with work-which added to her confiding in us, has been a big step forward for her. Brian and I met with our s.i.l a few evenings ago-and how he is suffering too. He admits he is running on empty, and is lost to see a way forward. Having him sit between us on the sofa, with tears streaming down his face, was a humbling lesson. He is still very committed to getting her well again-so we're hoping that working together, we may find a way forward. Just can't see my way out of it all at the moment-so apologies for not being around much of late-I'm just completely distracted. Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 02:38AM ElaineD wrote: I can see from your replies that you will get this checked out which is great, and this was what I was also going to suggest. You're right, that in the grand scheme of things, more lumps will appear-such is the nature of the disease at this stage, when progression is a fact of life. The important thing to remember is that any progression is the barometer we use to judge how efficient any treayment may be. So, if (and I stress "IF"), this transpires to be a further met, then perhaps some dosage adjustment is necessary? My onc works on the rough theory that any progression after 3 cycles means the treatment isn't helping, and will try something else. He scans after every 3 cycles so we have a continual picture (although when on drug trials, I was scanned after every 2 cycles, mainly so I could revert to conventional chemo when progression set in) It sounds as if Olga is being scanned after every 2 cycles? In which case changes may be made now, or after 4 cycles. Would you both be comfortable/confident waiting for another 6 weeks to see what happened? Obviously the main advise has to come from your onc, and patience is very difficult at this stage-but we have to give the drugs a chance to help. Whilst we may not see an immediate response, it's worrying when we see progression-stability, or the slowing down of the spread may be what you could hope for after 2 cycles, as this would give some indication that it was having some effect. If there is further progression, then it is worrying, naturally. In terms of the bone pain disappearing completely? This is something which may take longer-or which may never happen, depending on the location of the problem My bony mets still hurt-allthough some of the pain appears to be nerve pain (it responds reasonably well to gabapentin), as the tumours are pressing on nerves. Good luck with the scan-hoping there's an innocent explanation-but if not, and it's time to try another chemo, then good luck too with that. Incidentally xeloda was no help to me-and after 4 cycles I was hugely relieved to be taken off it, as my feet were in such a mess that I couldn't stand, let alone walk-and this was despite doing everything to keep them in as good condition as possible. With a young family, if Olga has any problem like this, then actually another chemo may give her a much better quality of life. I was fine for a few cycles, and then I quickly developed huge blisters around the side of my feet, under my toes, and on the soles of my feet-even moving a few yards was excrutiatingly painful. Obviously, had it been helping the tumours reduce, we would have persevered-but having no response, and such crippling side effects, had me very glad to see the back of that particular drug!

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2010 12:27PM ElaineD wrote: Grannydukes-as you progress further through this "journey", you will sadly come to realise that all of us need these drugs sooner or later. It's a hugely painful condition, and we would have no qol whatoever, if we tried to do without painkillers. Addicitive-I really don't care-I need these drugs, so am not going to tie myself in knots as to their potential downside-unless of course, I have allergic reactions to them, which of course is another issue completely.One of my worst fears was ("is"), dying a painful death-it still happens, even in this day and age. Of course the doctors prescribing these drugs would do so for their loved ones-they have seen far too many of their patients die painful deaths, to do otherwise.Further, I wouldn't worry too much about their addictive qualities-unless you have addictive tendencies in your life anyhow-plus, if you genuinely need them for pain, you won't become addicted. There is a world of difference between needing controlled pain relief, and abusing prescription medications. I'm really sorry that you feel you need to be in control-again, you will learn that with a stage 1V diagnosis, you have very little control over your life-it all revolves around how much the cancer "allows" you to do at any given time. One thing we certainly do not have is control. Whilst I admit that I admire a positive attitude (however unfashionable it is to admit to this), I think we are ultimately controlled by our disease-and we really have little choice other than to go with the flow, and make the most of our good days-and if we have a bad day, then hope that the next one will be better. As Barbie said, we are not lying at home popping pills mindlessly-we are taking what we need in order to be able to function.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2012 12:59PM ElaineD wrote: Not at all. The criteria for a trial is completley different to conventional treatment. It's standard procedure to wait up to a month to allow any residual drugs from your previous chemo to be removed from your system-othewise they would not be able to assess reliably if any changes were due to the previous/present drugs.Consequently, if she's keeping you on xeloda in the meantime, the delay unfortunately will be even longer.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 04:56AM ElaineD wrote: Speculating as to what it may be would be wrong of us. Only medics can establish exactly what, if anything, is happening. However, at this stage I would advise you to take a step at a time. Establish first if there is a primary cancer before you worry about potential metastatic disease! It would also be wise not to spend too much time looking for info on the internet at the moment-it can be like looking for the needle in the proverbial haystack. Once you have a firm diagnosis, then there will be plenty of questions you can ask-but until then, reading extensively is only going to cause you even more worry-and much of it will likley be unfounded. Hope all goes well.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 03:08AM ElaineD wrote: There's no doubt about it-it's a hard road. I vowed when I was diagnosed with mets (to pleura, liver+bone, Nov 2007), that I would not let cancer dominate my life.After the initial anger and fear, I think I'm coping reasonably well. It's hard to realise that we will always be on treatment (with an occasional chemo break if we're lucky!), but once I had acceptance of that, I found that mentally I felt stronger. This blasted disease will finish me physically one day, but it's not going to get me mentally, if I can help it. Someone here once said, "we can't change the road we're walking, but we can decide whether to walk it crying or smiling"-and I think that summarises it well. Like Janis, I pretty much live for the day-if it's a good one, I enjoy it:a bad one then I hope the next will be better....I'm not too good at planning much more than a month or so in advance-perhaps one day! I agree that we're far from a cure, and that there are still a lot of misconceptions about how far cancer treatment has evolved.But, we have to grab what treatments are available-and many of them actually aren't too bad- I coped ok with taxoterrible, for example! Plus the meds nowadays for the s/effects are very effective-be sure you get as many of them as you need, and this at least will help with the physical challenges. You can do it....

Posts.Title: Sometimes I feel like a cat. LC815 Kathy36

Posts.Content: ElaineD wrote: Our darling daughter is getting married on Saturday. Preparations for it have kept me busy and distracted for the past few months-what a bonus! We're looking forward immensely to the day-her fiance is a lovely guy, and we know he'll take care of her. At the same time, am expecting the day to be tinged with sadness. They don't plan on having children soon, so I guess I'll be unlikely to see any grandchildren. They may surprise us though-Jenny has the BRCA2 misprint, so will not likely delay for too long before thinking about kids. We bought her pearls to match her dress (which she was honest enough to say "weren't her"!!). We knew they weren't her taste, but just wanted her to have something specific to the day-but have since bought her an alternative-which she loves. The upside to this, is that I've decided to keep the pearls for me-so she'll get them eventually, whether she likes it or not, lol! They're a good match for a pearl ring I have which belonged to Mum-who tragically died of bc on her 50th birthday, so will be wearing them in memory of her. So...lots of emotions will be running high on Saturday-not a dry eye in the house, no doubt.....Just wish Mum (and Dad, who also died of cancer), were still with us. Jenny doesn't really remember Mum at all as she was only 3 when she died. Will post a pic of the happy couple next week-in the meantime, we're counting down the hours to this wonderful day in our lives.Fortunately, I should be at my good phase-had chemo last Wednesday, so am already pretty well recovered-which is as just well as we've got a ceilidh band coming in the evening to play for the dancing (we're Scottish). Not sure how energetically I'll be dancing-but I'll be doing my best. When diagnosed with mets back in Nov 2007, I really didn't expect to be dancing one day at our daughter's wedding.....I'm so grateful that I will be. Isn't it wonderful when we reach milestones we didn't think we would see? Dx 11/4/2007, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 07:25PM ElaineD wrote: I'm happy to stand up and be counted in the sceptic camp. Whilst I accept that the doctor is a respected researcher, I think that those who are expecting miraculous results in the near future need to stand back a little and actually examine what clinical trials involve. The man himself has emphasised that even if all goes to plan, it will be 15 years before this would become widely available. Let's face it, most of us (all?) will likely be dead by then. There is an excellent thread which details what trialling actually involves-and I suggest that the everyone takes a few moments to read it. Even if he gets funding, there is a long way to go. I wish you all well with your campaign-but am not convinced by the research so far. Had it progressd to phase 1 or 2 of human trials, then would be the time to get excited. In the meantime, it's much too soon. However nice and presentable he may be, there are many other research projects ongoing at present-and think the emphasis on this one comes down to saturation at press level-not a good basis for  accuracy and honesty. Please take a few moment to read the relevant thraed- http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/102/topic/756391?page=1#idx_6

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 01:12PM ElaineD wrote: Not at all. Time and again my team have gone the extra mile to do as much for me as they can. I consider them friends. They seem to be dedicated, work incredibly hard, and nothing is too much trouble. I know many oncology patients personally in this country -and I'm also on a UK forum, where I know many more, and I've never heard this complaint before. A very occasional query about delayed appointmets/scan results, etc, but nothing which makes us feel that we aren't being cared for to the best of the medics and system's abilities and restraints One thing I have noticed, which may contribute to the disatisfaction in the US-and this is pure speculation, if I am speaking out of turn, pleasee forgive me, and put it down to my ignorance. I read "active topics", and time and again , I see there, as well as on our 1V board, that second/third/ad infinitum opinions are sought. That of course, is everyone's right. But surely it has a knock on effect both on the system, and the medic's attitude towards their patients? If there was more trust forthcoming from patients, wouldn't the medics feel more confident about getting more involved with their patients? I've always felt that there is no right/wrong with treatment protocol-it's trial and error. Ask 3 oncs for their opinion and you'll get 3 different answers-how does that help clarify anything?This is not directly answering the question, but it has been something which has fascianted me-it's almost as if we trust our docs too much over here.The system and people are far from perfect, and chaos is looming on the horizon-but I know with all my heart that the people responsible for any downturn in the care we get will be the government cutbacks, not the staff at the cutting edge, who do a fantastic job under horrendous circumstances. I often joke with them that they would have a very easy life if it weren't for all these damned patients! But I'm sorry to see so many of you discontent with the care you receive-if the vulnerable, ill members of society can't be cherished and valued, then it's a sad state of affairs.Again, I apologise if my comment has offended anyone-I genuinely don't know enough about your systems to make any worthwhile comments, but have always been intrigued by the amount of discontent that is seen, re patients having to look for alternative opinions/change their onc. I can't imagine doing either, unless there had been some very serious breaches of etiquette,or perhaps when I get to the stage of my present team being unable to offer me any further options.

I'm 2 years post mets diagnosis, with 2 years continual chemo,and find each cycle that little bit harder to handle, and it takes longer each time to return to some semblance of normality. If you can stick with taxotere a bit longer, then it might be good to do so-when is your next scan? At this stage, I'm being scanned after every 3 cycles, so it sounds as if more regular scanning may at least give you an idea as to how effective a treatment is being-otherwise we can waste precious energy speculating. As he's using a much reduced dose, it could be that it would take longer to give some good results-another reason for keeping on with it if you can. You've done amazingly well so far-let's hope you can get some more good results which make all this suffering worthwhile.

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2009 05:06AM ElaineD wrote: Although I had my primary diagnosis when I was older than you (13 years ago when I was 40), I well remember the feelings of, "they've made a mistake", "could I be dreaming?" The latter was even worse, when I awoke first thing, and had forgotten all about it-you know that split second each day when you feel normal?I guess it's a bit of denial-we really don't want to believe that it could have happened-especially those of us who had tried to live as healthy a life as possible. But it does get better. You'll learn to live with it-and not let it dominate your life. I always feel that if we let it rule our lives and our waking thoughts, that in a way we have really let the cancer win-and you're not going to do that, are you!? Also, try not to let the "strong" comments upset you. Friends and family too are in shock, and many of them quite honestly don't know what to say. After all, they'll know even less about b.c than you do. It's only when a specific illness affects us or a loved one that we need to learn a little about it. I'm sure they mean well-are just upset and bewildered too. I know I've made similair comments to friends in the past-not necessarily about cancer, but with regard to the illness they are dealing with. Perhaps if these feeling continue for much longer you could ask to see a cousellor-it may help -it certainly seems to have helped many people. Good luck with the treatment.
Posts.Title: Not really understanding why I have BC 4lumps Hattie

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 06:47AM ElaineD wrote: No one chemo will be for life-they stop working for us sooner or later, and then we have to try another, in the hope of clawing our way back to where we had been before progression on the chemo set in. All we can do is focus as best we can on exploring every option for us when necessary, and trying to live in the present without allowing fear of our preamture demise consume us. Some people do respond well to various treatements and are able to take chemo breaks, which must be  a relief. It'll be tough for you-stage 1V is so different to an early stage cancer, so there is much still for you to get your head around. I would never dream of telling a new poster that "they'll be fine"-that's way too presumptious and we have no idea-not even our oncs know-how anyone will respond/fail to respond.But you will be fine, in taht you'll learn to live with it-sooner or later we all do! Hugs and best wishes to you.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 10:18AM ElaineD wrote: Your original post said this- "My 9 year old did ask and I told him No I don't have cancer and I am doing treatment to make sure I don't get cancer. He also knows his grandma and dad had cancer and both are fine. Welll my 9 year old said to me that his friend asked him if I had cancer. He told him the above.  Apprently his friend noticed I had on a wig." This is completely different to your second post when you said that you were the one who raised the topic. If the first version is the case, then he was asking a direct question-which your child psychologist had suggested that you should answer. If it was the second-  "He didn't come to me with his story about his friend. I actually asked him if he minded if I took off my wig-he said sure why would I care?", then it is slightly more problematic. But however you look at it, the topic has been raised and discussed, and it concerns me that you weren't honest with him.He would have required only the most basic questions answered, and this could have reassured him, wheras now he may have unresolved worries. I hope not-but perhaps if a similair situation arises in the future, it would be easier for him to be told the truth- as you said, your illness isn't impacting on their lives-that can be tremendously comforting. Hopefully too you will go on to live a happy and cancer free life once your treatment is completed-but if there are further problems, he will be confident in the knowledge that you have been honest with him in the past, and so can believe whatever you may need to add in the future.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2012 11:22AM ElaineD wrote: It will all depend on how well she responds to treatment. Whatever the outcome, she will need to be on some form of treatment for the rest of her life-and, believe me, that in itself is draining. Nobody can even begin to speculate how long your Mum may live-or at least, it would be irresponsible for us to do so-we are neither trained oncologists nor do we know anything about your Mum's health and emotional/mental attitude.However, since you asked the question, I would have to say that surviving 10+ years with liver mets is unlikely. Not unheard of, but unlikely. You could ask her onc for a prognosis-remembering that it is of course an estimate. Would you be prepared/strong enough to deal with bad news, if he gave you a prognosis, of say, a few months, or a few years? Please think long and hard before asking this question-because if you do get an unfavourable answer, you won't be able to forget it-and you won't get much comfort in that situation from us trying to reassure you by saying that nobody has an expiry date(you wouldn't believe the number of times we have to say this to posters). It really is a catch 22 situation. I have to say that personally, I have never asked for a prognosis. Hope the treatment goes well.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 12:35PM ElaineD wrote: Thank you so much girls. I'm now day 3 of increased meds-and what a difference it has made. There is still a few episodes of breakthrough pain, but most of the time I feel much more comfortable. I knew it made sense-I just had some kind of barrier holding me back. It's not so much the fear of addiction-rather the fear that I might need to move on to stronger pain relief quickly. I have this horrendous fear that one day my pain won't be controllable, so I try to use pain meds as sparingly as possible, in the hope of making them last as long as possible. Crazy, again, I know, but this blasted disease plays mind tricks on us too. I really needed to be taken in hand/shouted at. At times it's so easy for us to get wrapped up in ourselves that we can't see the wider picture. Rather than "poor you, that's terrible", sometimes short sharp tactics work far better-and this is a case in point. Brian also sends his thanks!

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 05:21AM ElaineD wrote: How far into you chemo are you? I'm stage 1V, so I've had 26 months so far! But at every cycle, I find sleeping very hard for the first week. I don't know if in part it is due to the other side effects-nausea, etc. But as I feel so very fatigued in the first week post chemo, I would expect/hope to sleep well-but I don't. To be honest, I don't take anything for it-I just go with the flow. I go to bed much later than is normal for me, and if I do get to sleep, but then wake in the middle of the night, I get up again and read for a while. I know this may not help you too much-but if you're at the start of your treatmnet, it's meant more to reassure you that it can/should be a temporary blip. Fon't forget too, that you are possibly still quite stressed? That alone can play havoc with sleep patterns. I'm sure you know all the usual tricks-no coffee/alcohol late at night, lavender on pillow, etc, so won't repeat the obvious! Good luck-hope it improves soon.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2009 10:11AM ElaineD wrote: Hi Lisbeth. So sorry to hear of your daughter's problems, and I'm sure she'll be glad to have you by her side. We all react differently to treatments, so it's hard to suggest what she might expect to feel like. Many of us manage not too badly at all-and even if we have bad side effects, there are many meds which we can be given to help ease the side effects-so make sure she doesn't suffer in silence through nausea/pain, etc. At this stage, I would suggest just take a day at a time. Don't look too far to the future, as there is so much information to take in, it can all get a bit confusing if you try to take it all on board straight away. Chop it all up into smaller chunks, and deal with problems when they arise. It's good that you are aware of the seriousness of the situation-but having said that, there are many treatments nowadays which aim to keep us stable for some years. Although you're right-metastatic cancer has no cure, we can still hope to live with it as a chronic condition for quite a while.So far, it has been contained in her bones, which is a relatively "good" sign, as the major organs as yet aren't involved, so let's hope she stays that way for a while. At this stage, we all will be on one form or another of treatment for the rest of our lives-but we sometimes get "chemo breaks" when the disease is stable-and some of us even have reprieves in the form of being NED ("no evidence of disease"). Ultimately, it does return, but nobody-not even the most experienced oncologist in the world-can really predict how our disease will behave and spread. So if you can, take each day as it comes, remain hopeful that her treatment will go well, and just be there for her as much as you can. She will likley feel quite tired at times, so will no doubt be glad of extra help with the kids. Don't be surprised/hurt if her moods change erratically, and she might lash out at those close to her-we all have our down days, when the fear just overtakes us-it's all perfectly normal under such horrendous circumstances. Good luck to you all-do keep us updated-and maybe suggest that she joins us here too?

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2010 01:09PM ElaineD wrote: You are not alone-you have us. I wish we could do more to help and support-because cancer is a loney place-even when we are surrounded by people we love, we can still feel alone. Anything you feel at the moment is normal-it's hard to handle-but it's normal. Sometimes we need to withdraw a little-I would say, if you want the comfort of familiar surroundings/being at home-then don't force yourself to do otherwise (unless you really need to go somewhere). I find my home to be my refuge, and when my spirits are low, all I want is to be there-just sitting quietly (and hopefully painfree!), reading a little,dozing, cuddling the dog.....On the other hand, on low days hubby has been inclined to want to take me out somewhere-and whilst his intentions are good, it took him  a while to realise that I would much rather be at home. Familiarity and routine can be strangely comforting. Today I had quite a busy morning doing housework, and baking-and how proud I was that I managed ok! Whoever would have thought that such simple things would be the source of pleasure and pride.....

Posts.Content: ElaineD wrote: We saw my onc tonight to get the results of last week's CT scan.Sadly the herceptin + exemestane alone hasn't been enough to stop the tumours growing, so we're starting back on chemo on Thursday-capacitabine this time. He didn't have the scan results to hand, but from the information that he'd been given earlier from the radiologist, the indication is that there has been "noticeable" change in the liver tumours (so he presumes at least 25%).  There is also signs of thickening in the pleura. We're naturally disappointed and upset-but realistically had little hope that herceptin+exemestane alone would be an adequate therapy. He's reluctant to put me back on taxotere at present, but may do so in the future. Just before we set out, I said to Brian "I'm not prepared for bad news"-I've been feeling physically and emotionally well , so this has been a bolt out of the blue. But in some strange way, I'm relieved to be going back on chemo. He'll see me again in 3 weeks, and scan again 2 months from now. On one hand, I'm dreading it-yet at the same time, I'll be glad to be having more treatment which might help slow down the progression. Comfortingly, he's said that there are still many drugs which he can try-it's still a bit of trial and error at the moment. Fingers crossed this combination may bring some good results. Only 2 months of stability though from taxotere+herceptin, so it's pretty nerve wracking at the moment. Dx 11/4/2007, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2010 03:59PM ElaineD wrote: Waiting to start chemo does make sense-although it's hard to take the logic on board. I look at it as a way of "saving up" our options for as long as possible. There will come a point when the chemo ceases to be effective (hopefully a long way in the future!) , or when the cummulative effect of the side effects of the chemo become too hard to bear.So, saving/spreading the chemo out over as long a period as possible does make sense. Posts.Content: May 26, 2011 10:53PM ElaineD wrote: Sorry to hear your news. But, the downside to looking for reassurance that all will be well-as your previous posts have done-is that when things don't go as well as hoped, then the acceptance that we have progression is even harder to bear. For this reason, I am always very wary about posting things like " it all sounds good", "all will be well". We simply don't know-all we can do is guess-even the oncs are working on guesswork to a large degree. One of the best peices of advice (thanks Katie), I have ever read here was- "Hope for the best, but prepare for the worst" We all of course want good results-and some of us get them. But we have to understand and accept that our situation are dire, and the unexpected can happen at any time. Even when things appear to be going well, the unexpected can still strike, leaving us confused, bereft and frightened. How is your wife dealing with this setback?
Posts.Title: Update-Not What We Wanted EllsJen5 dianaleo

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 10:13AM ElaineD wrote: Lori-have you been tested for the gene misprints yet? It would be a good starting point for you-if you test negative, then effectively Isabella will be at no higher risk than the population in general. Admittedly there are new genes being discovered, but as a rough rule of thumb, if you are negative, then her risk factor will be the same as the rest of the population. If you've done the test, and it's positive, then you do have more of a dilemna. I'm BRCA2-as is my daughter and several of my cousins. She was tested at age 21-which in the UK is seen to be as early as the geneticists like to do it-and for various reasons, they would actually prefer to leave it until the child was older. There's very little accurate monitoring that can be done at present until about the age of 30-so a positive diagnosis earlier, can potentially cause a huge amount of stress. But forever the optimist...genetics is such a rapidly evolving field, that it doesn't seem unrealistic to hope that in 20 or so years (by which time your daughter could start to be monitored if she does have a gene misprint), then who knows...it could be, if not curable, then a much more manageable disease.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2009 02:25PM ElaineD wrote: As with everything concerning cancer-there is no rule. I had no symtoms and was diagnosed with mets purely by chance. All I can suggest is that you try to remain rational, and not panic over every ache and pain. You will have things which happen in your life that have no connection to a previous cancer diagnosis. Try to remain as calm as possible, otherwise you run the risk of panicking over everything-and if you do that, then the cancer has truly won, as it dominates your thoughts.Don't go looking for trouble, where there may be none to be found. Even if you do get a mets diagnosis at some stage, a few weeks/months delay in having it confirmed makes no difference to the overall picture. But I would urge you to try and put this behind you as far as possible-dwelling on when/if you may gets mets is not good for your mental health and emotional well being. A degree of fear is natural-but don't let it run out of control.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 10:11AM ElaineD wrote: Thank you all so much- Brian is relieved to know that you have all made me see sense! What really struck me last night, was overall how I had managed to avoid the peaks and troughs of the pain levels simply by taking what I needed, when I needed it. Am mainly concerned with the newest pain, which is in the middle of the join in my ribs-assuming nodes, and gearing myself up to discover progression there. I saw my onc last week, and we are due to scan again next month, so all will be revealed in due course. What also occurred to me last night was the fact that until recently, I have only really needed occasional pain relief-so taking the step to regular dosages is a bit of a leap in itself. But on the plus side....when diagnosed with mets 2.5 years ago, I didn't even expect to survive this long. Yet here I am, managing overall not too badly at all, and just getting to the stage of needing to be more procative with pain relief. So, ready now to do what's needed from now on-I know it makes sense-I just needed a bit of persuasion!

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 08:56AM ElaineD wrote: If you're not HER2+ you won't get herceptin, so I have no idea why this has been suggested to you as an option. Herceptin also needs to be given at the same time/no later than 6 weeks after, chemo-yet another reason why you wouldn't qualify for the drug, as it appears you are 4 years post chemo? Herceptin can cause damage to the heart-but patients are closely monitored (usually every 6 weeks), and if the heart function detriorates, treatment stops immediately. Recovery usually follows quickly thereafter, and treatment can once again be started. But these sound almost academic points in your case, as I really don't think you would qualify for herceptin. Why did this second doctor suggest that you would?

Of course, if you were at the start (or anything up to midway), of the treatment plan, I would definitely be considering dose reductions-but can't see 1 more cycle impacting too severely. Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 12:08PM ElaineD wrote: Chica-I think your post is profound and admirable-and not at all negative. Understanding and beginning to accept what a stage 1V diagnosis actually means, can take a long time, and you have taken a big step forward towards achieving that goal. Honesty with yourself-and us-is not negative, but is something which we admire-or should! I'm not going to trot out the worn out old platitudes and tell you that you might get to NED for years. You're clearly a sensitive and intelligent girl, and great though it is to hear that there could be things which may help, we need to to prepare ourselves for the overwhelming despair which happens when we have bad scans, or when treatment fail us. I think one of the most difficult things I have to deal with is psyching myself up to try a new treatment-only to watch it fail (this has happened 3 times to date) Each time I think I'm prepared for disappointment-but the resultant devastation from treatments which fail is simply soul destroying. Like you, herceptin never seems adequate alone to hold my tumours. I had shrinkage on taxotere/herc, carboplatin/herc:but within weeks of trying herceptin alone, the growth restarted. I had tykerb (with xeloda, as that's the only use it's licensed for here), so can't comment on the efficacy of it with herceptin. But am pretty certain that someone has had good results with it. So let's hope you do too. Addressing your other point, re that cancer will likely be the cause of your death. Yes, that is true. It hurts like crazy-and again, I won't repeat the old cliche, "it might not happen". The likelihood is that it will happen. But where the heart of the tragedy lies, is not that we die from cancer (which is such a  complex series of diseases, that it's not surprising that the death rate remains high), but that we will die prematurely from the disease. You are much younger than me (I'm 54), have accepted that I may manage another few years-but that still feels like a premature death to me. People may say, "oh, you could be killed suddenly in a road accident"-as if dying prematurely in some other way is less of a tragedy! One of the very best peices of advice I have ever been given (here from Katie), was "hope for the best, but prepare for the worst"-and that sounds exactly what you are doing. It's very hard indeed, to pick ourselves up after treatment fails/bad scans-but somehow we do it. I guess because there is no other choice. Don't ever feel alone in these bad times-we do understand, and will help as much as we can,xx

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 10:57AM ElaineD wrote: With a stage 1V diagnosis, what your Mum has to understand that recurrence is inevitable-I'm not sure where 67% can come from! At this stage our oncs strive to keep us as healthy as possible for as long as possible, moving us between treatments when necessary. Some people will respond well, and have periods of being NED ("no evidence of disease"), some may remain stable, whilst other experience progression. It sounds as if her onc hasn't explained this very basic point to your Mum, and it is one that she needs to understand, otherwise she may see every set back as a failure, when in fact, it's just part of the new lives we have been forced to lead. There is no easy answer as to how best to live with it-taking a day at a time is probably the best advise I can offer, and try not to worry too much, if possible-if one day has been bad, then hope that the next will be better. Her scan is only a few weeks away, so she may hopefully get some good news then. But if not, rest assured that there are many drugs available that she will be able to try. Good luck.

I think this is one of the hardest things to accept-but in all honesty, there is little point in dwelling on it. We have enough to cope with in daily living. Yes we can deteriorate alarmingly quickly-when that final stage arrives, perhaps speed is no bad thing. I think I fear and dread, a slow and lingering death-how awful that would be for our loved ones. By that stage we can't be helped-except hopefully by remaining pain free-but I don't want my loved ones to suffer the agonies of me lingering, comatose or unrecognisable for a while.

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2009 08:09AM ElaineD wrote: Until you have a definite diagnosis, ther'es really not a lot you can do. It's not practical to research possible treatments before you know exactly what you are dealing with-and even then I would hope that you could trust your team enough to believe what they recommend. I honestly think looking for answers at the moment is only going to stress you further.Everyone with mets is scared-it's part of the life that we have to live. But don't let it dominate your life-relax as far as you can, try and get some enjoyment and pleasure in your daily routine....and when you know what you're dealing with (if it turns out to be anything significant), then you will be in a position to ask questions and do some research. At the moment you are going around in circles-you're not even sure what the question is, let alone the information you hope to find. We all want to begin our new treatments as soon as possible-but a delay of a few weeks while your team get the results they need is unlikely to make much difference. So in the meantime, please try not to panic. There will be time enough for that later-if the results show progression.Since you were NED in September,I would try and focus on that, and all that such a great diagnosis suggests. Incidentally, the er status can change, so it may not be that mistakes have been made. My er changed from - to + between primary and secondary diagnosis.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2009 11:34AM ElaineD wrote: Sorry to hear your news Wendy. I'm in quite a similair situation myself-in that varoius chemos have slowed progression in the mets in pleura and bone, but done nothing for the liver mets. I had reasonable success on taxotere, which reduced all by 50%, but when stopped, and relying simply on herceptin, they started growing very quickly again. I then had xeloda-for 6 months, which has seen further progression, so we've stopped that too (I had it in conjunction with tykerb) Naturally, these are huge blows, as we had high hopes of both these drugs. But we're all different, and you could respond very well to xeloda-all you can do is try and see....My onc has said the next combo he will use will be carboplatin and herceptin-but for the meantime, I'll likley be starting on drug trials for PARP inhibitors, as I'm also BRCA2. I fully understand why you're worried about the liver-it's my biggest concern too. Good luck,x

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2010 07:20AM ElaineD wrote: Both Linda and Stephanie have raised important points. Ok, 8 months may not sound long to the average "well" person, but at stage 1V, 8 months is quite a long time. By all means, hope and aim to squeeze longer out of each treatment, but also be prepared to accept that the reality may be very different. I would have loved to have got 8 months from my 2nd chemo (xeloda, which was no use to me at all). I think you really have to try and adjust the timeframe/mindset in your life. Any time given to us when we are stable/NED has to be welcomed. "A day at a time" as Linda said-this is my catchphrase. If you can get a run of success from various treatments, it could add up to quite a few years. This is my hope-and one which doesn't seem to unobtainable. I can't spend my precious time chasing rainbows, hoping for miracles-although of course I do both of these things, and certainly wouldn't refuse a miracle if it came my way! But having treatments which can be effective for a number of months/years is the reality we have-if you can learn to focus more on what you have in the present, and keep the fears for the future under control as far as possible, you may find it gives you a new found confidence in whatever the future may bring your way.

Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) anyone? lemon_acosta MrsJMS

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 02:22AM - edited Aug 23, 2009 06:34AM by ElaineD Thanks LuAnn. We seem to be doing it differently in the U.K. Here it s only open to BRCA1, BRCA2, and ovarian cancers. Theer is no intention to open it to TN at any stage in the near future. The next group to likely be included will be prostate cancer patients. It'll be interesting to compare results-and wouldn't it be incredible, if all categories benefited from it?So far, on my arm (BRCA2), they have had only 3 candidates, including myself. One girl had to drop out after 1 cycle of treatment as the side effects were too powerful for her, and the other girl has had her 12 cycles....and is going strong, and so is being kept on it. I hope to be like the latter! I'm finding it a pretty tolerable drug, although I have never experienced exhaustion like this. It hits me like running into  a brick wall, and has me completely weak for about 5 days. Pain levels also fluctuate considerably in the site of the tumours, so we're hoping that's tumour flare.

My feet are cracking and blistering, severely restricting my mobility, and cracks on my fingers are making some tasks very difficult. Posts.Title: Scan Results Back-very confusing kenzie57 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2009 07:28AM ElaineD wrote: The problem here is your sister's age. Breast tissue at this age is simply too dense for mammogrammes to be useful, so don't waste any time fighting for something which won't give clear results. An mri would be more suitable, and I think your sister would be well justified in having one. But, don't forget, even if your Mum's cancer was genetic, it's by no means certain that your sister witll have inherited the gene misprint. It may be that she-and you-would also consider genetic testing, to establish if your risk is higher than average? Good luck to you both.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2011 05:53AM ElaineD wrote: I'm also on chemo no 5 so I do sympathise. My first chemo was taxotere, to which I responded well-so last week, I asked if we would use it again at some point. To be told "no" as it would not likely work-partly as it was being reused, and partly because I had a limited response to taxol earler in the year.. Sadly, the oncs usually have their reasons for these type of statements-and it's up to each patient to ask him for as much or as little information as is pertinent to their own case.We can advise about side effects, etc., but no two cases will be the same-no matter how well something works for one person, it will fail dramatically for another-this has happened to me also with xeloda, which achieved nothing orther than progression, and caused me such horrendous side effects that I would have asked to be taken off it, had my onc not got there first! I hope your wife gets some response-and that you are aboe to enjoy a holiday.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 08:05AM ElaineD wrote: Thank you all! Lisa, tykerb is available here-but is only licensed with xeloda-a combiantion which we have already tried, and which failed spectacularly! Chris-I think you hit the nail on the head. If we can accept the likelihood of dying prematurely with as much grace as we can muster, it will make our daily life less fraught with anxiety. I do find taking a day/problem at a time helps enormously, but sometimes it feels almost a little like living in denial-and that's not my way at all! I have very much been thinking of Katie's recent experiences, and this gives me hope. Even when things appear to be at their bleakest, something can unexpectedly kick in and give us some breathing space, so to read her update today, has had me bouncing up and down with excitement (not a pretty sight!!!!)  Of course, nothing is straightforward for me at the moment.....I should have had taxol yesterday. But it isn't used in Exeter for b.c. (honestly!), although it is used for ovarian cancers, and the necessary paperwork hadn't been completed in advance-necessary as it was being used "out of protocol". My onc is on holiday, so it fell to one of his colleagues to try and sort out the mess-and 5 hours later we were still waiting. The nurses were so angry and frustrated on my behalf, and by 4pm suggested that we come home, and return today, by which time all the necessary documentation would be done. So off we set once again, after having wasted yet another day. Fortunately I received a phone call a short while ago saying that pharmacy was mixing up my cocktail, so we would be fine to proceed today. I'll believe it when it happens though! Thanks once again for all your kind wishes-I feel a little more in control each day, and feel that as long as we are trying as hard as we can to make progress, then we are doing our best. But I am firm with my onc-even if the options are diminishing, I'm nowhere close to withdrawing from treatment.

Posts.Content: ElaineD wrote: Hi girls. Have dropped in very briefly over the past few weeks. "I must try harder!" Seriously, haven't really felt up to contributing too much, but starting to feel a little better about things again-I guess sooner or later we usually do. Anyhow, just to let you know that our daughter had her first counselling/psychotherapy session last week, which went well. She was impressed with the counsellor, reassured that her problem can be addressed and treated succesfully-the more she hears this, the stronger she feels. A long hard road ahead for her, but she's taken the first step, and we're immensely proud of her. I'm still going around in circles, and getting frustrated with it all. Yesterday we should have been going to the Marsden in London to meet with the head of metastatic breast cancer research, to discuss various trials-in particular olaparib, which I am very keen to try.It's being developed as the next stage of inhibitor for those who have been on PARP, responded, then had progression-so I meet the criteria. However, having missed the worst of the weather so far, we awoke yesterday to 8" of snow. We tried to get to the station, but had to turn around after half a mile. We then needed to leave the car, as it was completely stuck-and still is! So no trip for me. Last week's treatment was split into two-herceptin and pamidronate last Friday:the first taxol being rescheduled for this Weds., to have enabled me to travel without too many side effects. It occured to me yesterday that I haven't had chemo now for 6 weeks-and so had the wash out period necessary for trials covered-ie, if all had gone well yesterday, I could have signed up to the trial, had all the testing done asap, and started on the trial, keeping taxol in reserve.However, this is not to be-and I'll start taxol on Weds as planned-sometimes things simply don't go as we want them to.... Must admit I'm still feeling a bit down about it-I can't get the fact that my onc feels we are running out of options, out of my head. I've had 4 chemos (taxotere, xeloda,carboplatin,navelbine), but still felt that there would be a good few alternatives for me. Surely there are more options for me-or am I really approaching my last few months? I know we deteriorate quickly and unexpectedly at times (far too often...). But overall, I don't feel to bad-low energy levels, pain pretty well controlled-but I'm far from spending long periods of time in bed-although I do need a sleep in the afternoons. I'm not in denial, I don't think, but am finding it very hard to accept that there are few options left for me. Dx 11/4/2007, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 03:25PM ElaineD wrote: Linda, I don't think you are actually disageeing terribly radically! My point is that it makes sense (to me at least), not to lay the blame for everything that goes wrong,( emotionally or physically,) at cancer (or the necessary drugs) door. We lose so much to the disease (how often do we get threads about friends who disappear from our lives, for example?), I feel that we must try to hold on to what degree of normality we may have. This will vary from person to person-but it makes me sooooo happy when I can continue to have some aspects of life which I can cope with in the way I used to do so. Small thigs become so important, and almost like goals which we strive to achieve. How often too do we read here "only you gals will understand"-and of course that's the case-and is one of the reasons I would prefer for this section to be open only to stage 1V patients or their supporters-as with any other illness, only those who have lived it can really understand-no matter how much empathy may come from other people/friends, etc. But-and I agree, it's a contentious issue. Let's try and look at it from our partner's point of view. If everything which goes wrong  is due to illness or drugs-then it doesn't seem as if the underlying emotional carnage is being dealt with. Granted there will be drugs which cause depression-as will the illness itself-you are actually agreeing with me by saying that the disease will dominate our lives, if we let it-I couldn't agree more, which was the whole point of my contribution. If we choose to be in denial (and/or assuming for example, that chemo will cause depression) strikes me as not facing the issue-and allows the disease another victory. Again, another unpopular concept, isn't it-seeing our lives with cancer as a battle? My main point however was simply not to assume that the illness or the drugs causes all the problems in our lives. Surely there would be a measurable proportion of those diagnosed who would suffer from depression, even if cancer hadn't touched their lives. And our partners have enough to deal with knowing that we have such drastically reduced life expectancy-is it really fair to them to bring every problem we experience back to cancer? Guess this conversation could run indefinitely-but as you said, we have to deal with side effects (or additional problems as the case may be), otherwise we will just get stuck in an ever decreasing circle of hurt and resentment.

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 08:45AM ElaineD wrote: Several years ago, I ended up hooked on tramadol. I badly needed it, but once we realised how it was affecting me, we worked to cut back the dosage. My doc was helpful and supportive, and we reduced it progressively over several months. I have no addctive tendencies (that I know of!), so this came as a real shock. I became aware of it when we had gone out for the day forgetting to take my meds with me-not only did I suffer because of the resultant pain, but I got into a fearful mess-shivering and shaking as I hadn't had the drug! Maddeningly it was an effective one for me, and one which has been suggested for use again-but I've declined. It is one which is well known for this-I just didn't expect me to be one of the ones who would get dependant. Please speak to your doc soon, and look into reducing the dose (under supervision), and trying an alternative. Good luck-it's a horrible experience-I'm just glad that you've realised what is happening, and can act to stop it getting any worse.
Posts.Title: Painkiller Dependency????? pupfoster1 hotandcold

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2010 12:10PM ElaineD wrote: I too am dealing with increasing levels of pain-and to be honest, although I have to tolerate the physical discomfort/pain, I really see no sense in beating myself up over what it means-I don't think I would be able to deal with that quite so well. It will likely be further progression-I had a scan on 11th, results will be with me on the 19th, and I shall be amazed if there is any other explanation. In the meantime, I'm blocking out the thoughts of the implications of this. More chemo added to the pamidronate and herceptin-that goes without saying. Will I respond-I don't know, so all I can do is try. I'm getting weary and frightened of how quickly things can change-guess my biggest fear is that things will become uncontrollable very quickly.Do you really think that the end is close for you? It sounds as if your involvement is still quite small-altough I'm surprised that with minimal liver involvement you are feeling pain-I have 3 tumours in my liver, and only have an occasional twinge-although that too is becoming more regular. In short, there is no secret formula as to how we cope. Some will find comfort in their religion, some live in denial, some grasp at the hope that a cure will materialise in time to save us. Whatever works for you-and it may not be the same as works for me. I'm just a stubborn girl, trying to live as long as I can, with as little pain as possible-and causing as little distress as possible to my darling family. It breaks my heart that I won't live to anything like an old age-yet count my blessings that I've made it to my 50s, when I see how many young girls we have with us here. All I can say is try and take a day at a time-and don't worry about what Thursday will bring in the meantime-worrying won't change the outcome. Looks like we both have heavy meetings that day-and I hope with all my heart that at least one of us has good news to report.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 10:11AM ElaineD wrote: I doubt very much that it's a paperwork error. Something similair happened with me.I began with mets to pleura and bones-and at one of my consults the onc sauid something along the lines of, "no change to the liver mets". I was astounded as I didn't realise I had liver involvement at that point-in some respects it didn't make any difference as I was on chemo anyway. But I would have appreciated knowing! Ann raised some good points. Some oncs give the minimum details, feeling we have enough to contend with-a valid point-and provided we are receiving treatment, no great harm is done. What bothers me more in your Mum's case, is the fact that the liver became involved.Bone involvement is a much less serious issue, and if the mets are contained in the bones is nowhere near as threatening as organ involvement. So to go from bone alone to organ involevement is a huge jump. In my case I had pleural involvement, so wasn't too surprised that there were other areas of concern. Your Mum might need to ask more direct questions-provided she wants the full picture. Some patients are happier living in denial, or some simply don't assimilate what they are being told. Perhaps at her next consult she could establish how much info she wants-I still am happy limiting the amount of info given (I don't know how many liver mets I have, for example!) I'm not in denial, as I fully understand all teh implications-but for the meantime I don't need to know every last detail-the overall picture suffices.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 02:05PM ElaineD wrote: I'm another with liver mets. It's challenging and distressing, and I fear to ask for a prognosis. I really feel that I have to try and live as far as possible in the present-but.....that's not to say that I'm being defeatist. Rather I have accepted as far as I can that the road ahead will be tough. I'm on carboplatin+herceptin at the moment, but fear that last week's scans will show further progression-so am already thinking ahead to asking if I can have taxotere added in to the mix. Please, please, try not to google much more. Take each step at a time, and don't look too far ahead-just deal with problems when and if they arise. What will work for some, may be of no use whatsoever to another-so it's difficult to supply any generalisation about how effective any one treatment may be-and of course, this too makes generalisations about prognosis, very dubious, to say the least. But, we can help and support continuously-and that alone is of great help in this horrendous disease we are living with. Good luck next week.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 01:52PM ElaineD wrote: I really wouldn't assume that the pain on your right could be liver mets-it could be, of course it could be. But until you know for definite, the please don't stress too much. The chemo has worked on your existing mets-which is fantastic news.Has your onc arranged a scan? If it is liver mets, it does seem to be true that they are more resistant to chemo than other locations-several times I have found that I have had reduction/stability in other areas (I have mets to pleura, liver and bones), whereas the liver mets are more stubborn and tend to progression. You are right-nobody but your onc can make a diagnosis to what (if anything), the problem is-but don't assume the worst until you have some firm evidence. Once again, I shall repeat my oft quoted mantra: "Hope for the best, but prepare for the worst" (Although if you wanted a guess, I would suggest that there is a very high probabilty of there being an innocent explanation-it's all to easy at stage 1V to assume that every ache=progression/spread). Good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2009 03:40AM ElaineD wrote: I'm BRCA2-as are my son and daughter. Several cousins are also carriers, two of which are males, so yes, males too need to be screened if a mutation is found in a first degree primary member of he family. I hadn't been diagnosed with mets when I had the test-but had had the second breast removed, and also a prophylactic mastectomey, so I thought I was as safe as I could be-but yet it came back....My reason for testing was to establish if other family members needed to be more vigilant, and I'm so glad-as is everyone else-that I did so. Several of the cousins have already had prophylactic surgery, and one will do so when she's older. As to my daughter....she too will likley go ahead with surgery. It broke my heart to have passed this on, but without exception, all are glad they know they have the misprint. Prevention may supposedly be better than cure (although no amount of surgery stopped me developing mets, so I have mixed feelings on that!), but if nothing else, we at least have the comfort of knowing that affected family members are closeley monitored-and would if necessary, be prioritised in the system. Small comfort, but it's something.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 09:49AM ElaineD wrote: Stacey-you do have time on your side. I appreciate that you have been worried for a long time, and feel that this would give you peace of mind. Granted having bilateral mastectomies would reduce your risk-but it doesn't remove the risk entirely. It's impossible to remove all the tissue, so it could still happen, even after surgery. Granted, the risk will be much smaller, but please don't think that surgery  would be a guarantee. I think if you persevere, you will convince them-it's just the way the system works in this country! (I'm in Devon-where are you?) In fairness they have to be very, very sure that the decision is the right one for you. If you can remain calm and focused, presenting the same arguments, then they will likley agree. If you have the genetic test done, and if it's positive, you will be able to enlist the help of  a genetic consultant, and that would possibly be enough to tip the balance. I think in fairness to the drs, they are probably not dismissing you as reacting on a whim-it's a huge decision to be made at any age. You're in a very vulnerable place at the moment, and with no evidence of a genetic misprint, and no family support, I feel they are trying to protect you rather than putting obstacles in your way. If you want to pm me to chat further, then please don't hesitate. Wishing you well, xx

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2009 03:55AM ElaineD wrote: Amy so sorry to hear your news-of course you're still in shock. It can take a while to come to grips with, so don't try and rush things. And please.....don't ask for survival statistics! Your onc has already upset you by giving you an "average", so, please, please don't look around for more statistics along that line (as you did at the end of your second post). They are only figures, and neither your medical team, statiticians, nor ourselves can give you any clue as to where you will fall in these figures. All figures can do is upset you-if you hear the time is short, it's devastating:if you hear that there could be a reasonable prognosis, and we continue to have progression, the upset is equally great. Take a day at a time-move forward slowly,and once treatment starts, some of the pressure will ease.Good luck.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2011 05:51AM ElaineD wrote: I'm sure I answered your question on another forum-but just in case.... It's a hard one to treat, and attempting to look so far into the distance is on;y going to upset you. We generally reckon surviving a bit less is good for liver mets-although there may be the occasional person who can survive longer. But as I said, all will depend on how well you can respond to treatment, and there is no way of knowing how that will go. I'm sure any of us would go anywhere in the world to get the treatment we long to have-but for the meantime, follow your oncs recommendations-only he/she knows and understands the full implication of your diagnosis. Please try to focus on the present-once you start treatment you will begin to feel better, in that you'll be hopefully doing something to stop it spreading further. We all hope to outlive the statistics, but iy would be irresponsible of us to say that this condition isn't terminal-if you can get to NED, it would be wonderful, and it could last for you for a while. But be prepared for setbacks too-it's heartbreaking when we read posts about treatments failing-all the more so when the patient isn't prepared for this eventuality. Good luck

Posts.Content: May 31, 2010 10:57AM ElaineD wrote: Yes, Stephanie, I well remember the wall staring. On mets disagnosis, this was literally all I could do for four days...and then I decided that however long or short the rest of my life was going to be, I wasn't go to spend it staring at walls. This is not to say that you need to live every day like it's your last (a well meaning frined suggested that I should do so....hmmm, that would be pretty exhausting, don't you think?) But, I aim to get to the end of each day and reflect, "I've done my best today". If you don't want to hear what your onc has to say-then ask him not to give you too much information. You don't have to know every detail about your treatment or your prognosis (I've never asked for a prognosis, and doubt that I ever will). Staying rooted in the present is a strategy which works for me-I still plan ahead....just not too far ahead. As Robin said-so much can change so quickly-one day we feel great as we've had good scans-a few weeks later we find we aren't responding any more to the treatment which gave us these good scans... It's an emotional nightmare, and the best you can do is live with it to the best of your ability-and we'll be here to rejoice in the good times you have , and prop you up when the going gets tough. Both scenarios will happen, but for the mantime, it's early days, so concentrate on just taking a day at a time until you feel a little stronger.
